revision.text:
An '''advertorial''' is an [[advertisement]] in the form of editorial content. The term "advertorial" is a [[blend word|blend]] (see [[portmanteau]]) of the words "advertisement" and "editorial." [[Merriam-Webster]] dates the origin of the word to 1946.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/advertorial|title=Advertorial - Definition from the Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary|publisher=Merriam-Webster|accessdate=2009-01-10}}</ref>
In printed publications, the advertisement is usually written to resemble an [[Objectivity (journalism)|objective]] article and designed to ostensibly look like a legitimate and independent news story. In television, the advertisement is similar to a short [[infomercial]] presentation of products or services. These can either be in the form of a television commercial or as a segment on a talk show or variety show. In radio, these can take the form of a radio commercial or a discussion between the announcer and representative. The concept of internet-based advertorials is linked to [[native advertising]]; however, whether the two terms are [[synonym]]ous is a point of discussion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digiday.com/publishers/native-ads-or-advertorials/|title=Native Ads or Advertorials?|last= Sternberg|first=Josh|publisher=''[[Digiday]]''|date=September 25, 2012 |accessdate=July 30, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedrum.com/opinion/2014/02/28/when-native-advertising-not-just-glorified-advertorial|title=When is native advertising not just glorified advertorial? |last= Turner|first=Francis|publisher=The Drum|date= February 28, 2014|accessdate=July 30, 2015}}</ref>
==Types== Advertorials can be classified into three types: * Image advertorials: The organization running the advertisement wants to produce a favorable view of the organization or its products among the readers.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gZB0NjVq3goC&pg=PT142|title=Governing Health: The Politics of Health Policy|last=Weissert|first=William G.|last2=Weissert|first2=Carol S.|date=2012-07-13|publisher=JHU Press|year=|isbn=9781421408460|location=|pages=142|language=en}}</ref> * Advocacy advertorials: The organization wants to explain their view of a controversial subject.<ref name=":0" /> * Journalism advertorials: The organization wants to attract media attention to a subject or themselves.<ref name=":0" /> Their goal may be inspiring independently written stories about their area of interest, to get quoted in related stories, or to influence how journalists will write about a subject in the future.
==Publications== Advertorials differ from traditional advertisements in that they are designed to look like the articles that appear in the publication. Most publications will not accept advertisements that look exactly like stories from the newspaper or magazine they are appearing in. The differences may be subtle, and disclaimers—such as the word "advertisement"—may or may not appear. Sometimes terms describing the advertorial such as a "special promotional feature" or "special advertising section" are used. The tone of the advertorials is usually closer to that of a [[press release]] than of an objective news story.
Advertorials can also be printed and presented as an entire newspaper section, inserted the same way within a newspaper as store fliers, comics sections, and other non-editorial content. These sections are usually printed on a smaller type of [[broadsheet]] and different [[newsprint]] than the actual paper, along with different fonts and column layouts. Many newspapers and magazines will assign staff writers or freelancers to write advertorials, usually without a [[byline]] credit. A major difference between regular editorial and advertorial is that clients usually have content approval of advertorials, a luxury usually not provided with regular editorial.
A related practice is the creation of material that looks like traditional media (for instance, a newspaper or magazine) but is actually created by a company to market its products. One familiar example is airline in-flight magazines, which may feature reports about travel destinations to which the airline flies.<ref name="Adair">{{cite web|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2006/09/10/news_pf/Worldandnation/Corporate_spin_can_co.shtml|title=Corporate spin can come in disguise|last=Adair|first=Bill|publisher=St. Petersburg Times|accessdate=2009-01-10| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090103194045/http://www.sptimes.com/2006/09/10/news_pf/Worldandnation/Corporate_spin_can_co.shtml| archivedate= 3 January 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
In 1996, a UK based company called Parkway Publishing began publishing advertorials for advertisers. Parkway began enlisting clients and created PRPros to function as PR via advertorials with great success. The cottage industry is now widely used and considered very successful. Sheldon Schorr, the president of Parkway, was a leader in the crafting of advertorials and placed hundreds a year in scores of periodicals, especially magazines, utilizing quotes, brand references and trade enhancement, "meant to compliment a company or persons' brand passively and more affordably than any other form of editorial content with much greater success than a press release". Historically, advertorials were less frowned upon and newspapers would even "show how magazine advertising is serving the public".<ref>See foot note in: {{cite news |title=The Making of a Cleanly Nation |url=https://archive.org/stream/independen79v80newy#page/n50/mode/1up |newspaper=The Independent |date=Jul 6, 1914 |accessdate=August 1, 2012}}</ref>
==Television== Advertorials on television are longer than typical [[television advertisements]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n3Vi0RyXc5wC&pg=PA279|title=The Entertainment Industry: An Introduction|last=Moss|first=Stuart|date=2010|publisher=CABI|year=|isbn=9781845935511|location=|pages=279|language=en}}</ref> They are usually played on cable and satellite channels, which are less expensive than broadcast television.<ref name=":1" /> They may include a [[Plot (narrative)|plot]] or story line to increase the entertainment value for viewers, and thus hold their attention longer.<ref name=":1" />
Daytime programs featuring light talk designed to draw in mainly a female audience often use advertorial segments which feature presentations of products, services, and packages by businesses. A representative of a business will have a discussion with a regular host, along with perhaps making a special offer for viewers.
===Australia=== In Australia, daytime programs featuring light talk and advertorials have been in television schedules since the late 1960s. One of the first was ''[[Good Morning Melbourne]]'' starring Roy Hampson and Annette Allison which began in 1967 followed by ''[[Good Morning Sydney]]'' in 1978, hosted by Maureen Duvall. [[Nine Network]] produced similar shows like ''In Sydney Today'' and ''In Melbourne Today'', later merged into ''Ernie and Denise'' in 1994. They were followed by a national program which began in 1992 on [[Network Ten]] called [[GMA with Bert Newton|Good Morning Australia]] (formerly The Morning Show) with Bert Newton. This success of that show prompted the [[Nine Network]] to launch a competing program in 2002 presented by [[Kerri-Anne Kennerley]] titled ''[[Mornings with Kerri-Anne]]'', later shortened to ''Kerri-Anne''. The Seven Network followed suit with a show starring [[Denise Drysdale]] called ''Denise'' before the debut of ''[[The Morning Show (TV program)|The Morning Show]]'' in 2007. Network Ten had ''[[9am with David & Kim]]'' from 2006 which was replaced by ''[[The Circle (TV program)|The Circle]]'' in 2010. In November 2011, Nine Network cancelled Kerri Anne which was replaced by a new program titled 'Mornings' which premiered in 2012 presented by [[Sonia Kruger]] and [[David Campbell (Australian musician)|David Campbell]]. It was later rebranded as [[Today Extra]] which mean't the show was tied closer to Nine's breakfast news program [[Today (Australian TV program)|Today]]. These programs feature a traditional daytime show format of light talk, health, beauty, fashion and recipe segments along with advertorial segments scattered throughout the show. The advertorials are usually hosted by regular advertorial hosts who interact with business representatives. The main hosts of the show usually do not interact with the advertorial hosts or the business representatives. Advertorials are regulated under the Commercial Television Industry Code of Practice, which has been registered by the Australian Broadcasting Authority.
===India=== In India, the nexus between cable television companies, popular news papers and political parties came to the fore front in a 2011 documentary made by [[Prasar Bharati]] which revealed that the ownership of seven of the ten largest media companies in India was connected to some political party or the other.<ref>{{cite web |title=The open frame - an informative documentary on Indian media |url=http://prasarbharati.org/index.php |website=prasarbharati.org |publisher=Public service broadcasting trust and Prasaar Bharati |accessdate=5 June 2018}}</ref> This was given further credence to reports on [[Paid news in India|paid news]] that appeared in 2015-18 in selected Indian news papers and channels connecting the dark links between the two largest political parties BJP and Congress, black money and payments made to media channels to paint them in a better light. In 2018, a sting operation nicknamed "Cobrabost 136" by [[Cobrapost]], an Indian investigative journalism agency showed videos of meetings held with the 15 largest media companies, who agreed to publish / telecast communally and politically motivated and misleading information as a campaign in return for payments, routed through advertising and PR companies.<ref>{{cite news |title=Media companies in India - cobrapost sting 136 |url=https://cobrapost.com/blog/Hindustan%20Times |accessdate=5 June 2018 |publisher=Cobrapost |date=1 May 2018}}</ref>
===United States=== In the United States, locally produced daytime television rose in the mid-2000s as local television stations (especially those with the [[NBC]] and [[Fox Networks]], where NBC gave up the most programming time) saw network time on [[daytime television|weekday mornings after 9am]] returned to local control and saw new national talk shows either fail or not attract the right [[demographic]] to a timeslot. Beginning with ''Daytime'' on [[Media General]] station [[WFLA-TV]] in [[Tampa, Florida]] in the early 2000s, a new format featuring the structure of a traditional locally produced daytime show with the usual format of light talk, health features, beauty tips and recipe segments which was popular up to the early 1990s (when expansion of newscasts became a much less expensive, more dependable form of revenue) came into use. Some of these shows, such as [[WKBW-TV]]'s ''[[AM Buffalo]]'' in [[Buffalo, New York]], seamlessly made the transition from a traditional local talk show to a paid program with little notice.
This type of program usually features light talk designed to draw in mainly a female audience, and then presentation of products, services, and packages by local businesses; for example a basement waterproofing system might be discussed by the representative of a company in that business with the hosts, along with perhaps a special offer for viewers.
In U.S. newspapers, for example, [[ExxonMobil]] purchased an advertorial on ''[[The New York Times]]'' op-ed page every Thursday between 1972 and 2001.<ref>{{cite journal |first1=Geoffrey |last1=Supran |first2=Naomi |last2=Oreskes |authorlink2=Naomi Oreskes |title=Assessing ExxonMobil's climate change communications (1977–2014) |year=2017 |journal=[[Environmental Research Letters]] |volume=12 |number=8 |doi=10.1088/1748-9326/aa815f |url=http://iopscience.iop.org/article/10.1088/1748-9326/aa815f}}</ref><ref>{{YouTube|id=w5g1nPfXOIA|title=Academic study concludes Exxon Mobil misled on climate change}} August 23, 2017 [[PBS NewsHour]]</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/scientific-study-concludes-exxon-mobil-misled-climate-change/ |title=Academic study concludes Exxon Mobil misled on climate change (with transcript) |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=August 23, 2017 |website=PBS NewsHour |access-date=August 28, 2017 |quote=And yet, 15 years after that study was released in “The New York Times,” Exxon released an advertorial saying [[Climate change skeptic|unsettled science]] was the rule of the day, and it quoted data from other studies which seemed to suggest it was natural fluctuations. The authors of that study said it was extremely misleading.}}</ref>
==Radio== On radio, advertorials can feature discussions between an announcer or a DJ and the representative of a business. The discussion may feature testimonials from customers or a personal endorsement from the announcer. The products featured can range from mobile phone/cable/satellite providers, insurance, financing, auto servicing, travel agencies, and upcoming concerts or music releases.
===Australia=== The "[[cash for comment affair]]" was an Australian scandal that broke in 1999, concerning paid advertising in radio that was presented to the audience in such a way as to sound like editorial commentary.
==Legal issues== In the United Kingdom, the [[Advertising Standards Authority (United Kingdom)|Advertising Standards Authority]] requires advertorials to be clearly marked as such. In one case, the Scottish newspaper ''[[The Herald (Glasgow)|The Herald]]'' published a feature titled "Professional Brief" that had been submitted by Glasgow-based French Duncan Chartered Accountants. According to a complaint, it did not clearly indicate that it was a paid advertisement. The newspaper argued that, because it was a "sponsored column" and it was indicated that the opinions expressed were those of the author, it did not have to refer to it as an advertisement. The ASA responded that, because payment was given in exchange for the publication of the columns and because the content was provided by the marketers rather than the newspaper, they considered the columns advertisements and required that they indicate as much.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.out-law.com/page-4853|title=Advertorials must be clearly identified|date=Jan 9, 2007|publisher=[[Out-Law.com]]|accessdate=2009-01-09| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090207072448/http://www.out-law.com/page-4853| archivedate= 7 February 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
For magazines in the United States mailed at the publication rate, the [[United States Postal Service|Postal Service]] has regulations as to how to mark editorial and advertising. [[Domestic Mail Manual]] states that under 18 USC 1734, "if a valuable consideration is paid, accepted, or promised for the publication of any editorial or other reading matter in a Periodicals publication, that matter must be plainly marked 'advertisement' by the publisher. When a single item of paid editorial or other reading matter occupies more than one page, it need only be marked 'advertisement' on the first page. The word "advertisement" may be included in a statement that explains why the material is marked 'advertisement.' Such a statement must be prominent on the first page of the material and the word 'advertisement' in the statement must be in bold or italicized print or otherwise emphasized so that it can be plainly seen. Editors or publishers who print such matter without plainly marking it 'advertisement' are subject to a fine of not more than $500."<ref>[http://pe.usps.com/text/dmm300/707.htm#1299866 "DMM 707 Periodicals"]. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050407185820/http://pe.usps.com/text/dmm300/707.htm#1299866 |date=April 7, 2005 }}</ref>
==See also== {{wiktionary|advertorial}} * [[Advertising supplement]] * [[Native advertising]] * [[Informative advertising]] * [[Indian paid news scandal]] * [[Mat release]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox court case |name = Amsterdam Sexual Abuse Case |court = [[Gerechtshof Amsterdam]] |image = |imagesize = |imagelink = |imagealt = |caption = |full name = |date decided = {{start date|2012|06|24}} |citations = {{ECLI|ECLI:NL:GHAMS:2013:BZ8885}} (Appeal) |transcripts = |judges = W.M.C. Tilleman, A.M. van Woensel and. N. van der Wijngaart |number of judges = 3 |decision by = |concurring = |dissenting = |concur/dissent = |prior actions = |appealed from = Rechtbank Amsterdam {{ECLI|ECLI:NL:RBAMS:2012:BW6148}} |appealed to = [[Hoge Raad]] ([[cassation]]) |subsequent actions =*opinion [[advocate-general]] {{ECLI|ECLI:NL:PHR:2014:632}} *decision Hoge raad {{ECLI|ECLI:NL:HR:2014:2668}} |related actions = |opinions = |keywords = |italic title = }} The '''Amsterdam sex crimes case''' ({{lang-nl|Amsterdamse zedenzaak}}) is a court case involving Robert Mikelson's abuse of babies in [[Amsterdam]], the [[Netherlands]]. The [[defendant]] was Roberts Mikelson,{{cite news|language=Dutch |accessdate=17 April 2012 |date=14 March 2012 |url=http://www.elsevier.nl/web/Nieuws/Nederland/333269/Geen-nieuwe-rechters-in-Amsterdamse-zedenzaak.htm |title=Geen nieuwe rechters in Amsterdamse zedenzaak |author=Marlou Visser |work=[[Elsevier (magazine)|Elsevier]] |trans-title=No new judges in Amsterdam Sex Crime Case }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} dubbed "the Monster of Riga" by the Dutch press,{{cite news |title=Robert Mikelson Pedophilia Conviction: 'Monster of Riga' Sentenced to 18 Years |author=Toby Sterling |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/05/21/robert-m-pedophilia-conviction_n_1532428.html?ref=world |newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=21 May 2012 |accessdate=31 May 2012}}{{cite news |title='Monster of Riga' Dutch pedophile sentenced to 18 years in jail |author=Luke Browne |url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/europe/benelux/120521/monster-riga-dutch-pedophile-sentenced-18-years-jail |publisher=[[GlobalPost]] |date=21 May 2012 |accessdate=31 May 2012}} who had worked at several [[daycare]] centres in Amsterdam and was accused of abusing 67 children{{cite news|language=Dutch |accessdate=17 April 2012 |date=16 April 2012 |url=http://binnenland.nieuws.nl/692334/advocaten_vinden_bewijs_robert_m_illegaal# |title=Advocaten vinden bewijs Robert Mikelson |work=Nieuws.nl }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} as well as possession, production and distribution of [[child pornography]]. Mikelson was found guilty and sentenced to 18 years and 11 months in prison, followed by [[involuntary commitment]]. ==Identification and arrest== The case of convicted sex offender Robert Mikelson started in December 2010 with the broadcast in the Netherlands on the television show ''Opsporing Verzocht'' ("Investigation Requested") of images originating from the United States.{{cite web|accessdate=17 April 2012|date=13 December 2010|url=http://www.dutchnews.nl/news/archives/2010/12/babysitter_abused_filmed_up_to.php|title='Babysitter abused, filmed up to 50 young children in Amsterdam'|work=DutchNews.nl}} Robert Mikelson and an unnamed child with a [[stuffed toy]] known as [[Miffy]] ({{lang-nl|Nijntje}}). As Miffy is originally a Dutch product, the investigators suspected the child to be Dutch. After the boy's grandfather realized the boy was his grandson, the police were directed to the child's [[Babysitter|sitter]], Robert Mikelson.{{cite news|language = Dutch|accessdate = 17 April 2012|date = 13 December 2010|url = http://www.ad.nl/ad/nl/3322/Misbruik-in-Amsterdamse-creches/article/detail/1911039/2010/12/13/Nijntje-knuffel-leidde-politie-naar-Robert-Mikelson.dhtml|title = Nijntje-knuffel leidde politie naar Robert Mikelson |author = Suzanne Borgdorff|work = [[Algemeen Dagblad|AD]]|trans-title = Stuffed toy "Miffy" pointed police to Robert Mikelson}} During a search of his house, computers containing a large collection of child pornography (46,803 photos and 3,672 movies, part of which had been unsuccessfully deleted during the broadcast) were found and seized,{{cite news|language=Dutch|accessdate=17 April 2012|date=12 March 2012|title=Behoud spreekrecht in zedenzaak|work=[[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting|NOS]]|url=http://nos.nl/artikel/350680-behoud-spreekrecht-in-zedenzaak.html}} resulting in ==Defendants== Roberts Miķelsons (in the Netherlands generally referred to as Robert M.) (born in [[Riga]], [[Latvia]], 14 September 1983) became a naturalized Dutch citizen in 2008. He was convicted of possession of [[German porn|child pornography in Germany]] in 2003 while working at a daycare facility in [[Heidelberg]].{{cite news|language=Dutch |accessdate=17 April 2012 |date=16 December 2010 |url=http://www.rnw.nl/africa/bulletin/parliament-shocked-about-earlier-conviction-robert-mikelsons |title=Parliament shocked by earlier conviction Robert Mikelsons |work=[[Radio Netherlands Worldwide]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120830094917/http://www.rnw.nl/africa/bulletin/parliament-shocked-about-earlier-conviction-robert-mikelsons |archivedate=30 August 2012 |df=dmy }} In 2004, he married Richard van O.. From 2007 to 2009, he worked at several daycare centres of "het Hofnarretje" group, and from 2009 to 2010, at "Jenno's Knuffelparadijs".{{cite news|language=Dutch|accessdate=17 April 2012|date=13 December 2010|url=http://www.parool.nl/parool/nl/4204/Zedenzaak-kinderdagverblijven/article/detail/1072173/2010/12/13/Directeur-Het-Hofnarretje-is-verbijsterd.dhtml|title=Directeur Het Hofnarretje is verbijsterd (Director Het Hofnarretje is bewildered)|work=[[het Parool]]}} According to evaluations of the [[Pieter Baan Centre]], a forensic psychiatric observation clinic, M. is a [[hypersexuality|hypersexual]] [[pedophile]] with a [[personality disorder]].{{cite news|language=Dutch|accessdate=17 April 2012|date=25 November 2011|url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/vk/nl/4244/Kindermisbruik/article/detail/3049946/2011/11/25/Langdurige-tbs-Robert-M-noodzakelijk.dhtml|title='Langdurige tbs Robert M. noodzakelijk' ('Long term involuntary commitment Robert M. necessary')|work=[[de Volkskrant]]}} Richard van O. (referred to as Richard van O.), is accused of possession of child pornography as well as sexual assault on an 11-16-year-old boy, both of which he was acquitted. He is charged with being an accessory to the crimes of Robert M. ==Victims== M confessed to the abuse of 83 young children, but he is charged with abuse of 67 because some of the parents preferred to keep their children out of the court records owing to privacy concerns.{{cite news|url=http://www.rnw.nl/english/bulletin/amsterdam-child-sex-abuse-victims-demand-damages|title=Amsterdam child sex abuse victims demand damages |date=2 April 2012|work=Radio Netherlands Worldwide|accessdate=26 April 2012}} The youngest of these children was 19 days old at the time the acts were committed.{{cite news|language=Dutch|accessdate=17 April 2012|date=19 March 2012|url=http://www.ad.nl/ad/nl/3322/Misbruik-in-Amsterdamse-creches/article/detail/3227776/2012/03/19/Jongste-slachtoffer-Robert-M-was-19-dagen-oud.dhtml|title=Jongste slachtoffer Robert M. was 19 dagen oud|author=Suzanne Borgdorff|work=[[Algemeen Dagblad|AD]]}} The abuse took place at the child care facilities where M. worked, at the homes of the children he babysat, and at M. and Van O's home. M. admitted abusing the children and suggested, according to media reports, that more children might have been involved. According to the prosecution ({{lang-nl|Openbaar Ministerie}}), M. carefully scouted his babysitting addresses for presence of heavy curtains and absence of [[nanny cam]]s. He stopped the abuse when the children started to be able to talk.{{cite news|language=Dutch |accessdate=17 April 2012 |date=5 April 2012 |url=http://nieuwsuur.nl/onderwerp/359282-eis-tegen-robert-m-20-jaar-en-tbs.html |title=Eis tegen Robert M.: 20 jaar en tbs (Charge against Robert M.: 20 years and involuntary commitment]) |work=[[Nieuwsuur]] |author=Gert Janssen and Jan van Loenen |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120408232050/http://nieuwsuur.nl/onderwerp/359282-eis-tegen-robert-m-20-jaar-en-tbs.html |archivedate=8 April 2012 |df=dmy }} ==Trial== The trial started on 12 March 2012 in the Court of Amsterdam ({{lang-nl|Rechtbank Amsterdam}}), a Dutch [[court of first instance]]. It took place at "de Bunker", a strongly defended courtroom in [[Amsterdam Nieuw-West]].{{cite web|language=Dutch|accessdate=17 April 2012|date=6 March 2012|url=http://www.parool.nl/parool/nl/4204/ZEDENZAAK-KINDERDAGVERBLIJVEN/article/detail/3220062/2012/03/06/Slachtoffer-in-zedenzaak-boven-alles.dhtml|title=Slachtoffer in zedenzaak boven alles|work=[[het Parool]]|author=Hanneloes Pen}} During the preliminary motions the parents of the children were granted the right to speak during the trial (a right normally only granted to direct victims), a decision which was challenged by M.' attorneys. Upon the granting of the right to speak, his lawyers ([[Wim Anker]] and Tjalling van der Goot) requested [[Substitution (law)|substitution]] ({{lang-nl|wraking}}) of the three judges, which was denied.{{cite web|language=Dutch |accessdate=17 April 2012 |date=14 March 2012 |url=http://www.bnr.nl/programma/juridischezaken/515650-1203/wrakingsverzoek-robert-m.-afgewezen |author=Pieter van den Akker |title=Wrakingsverzoek Robert M. afgewezen |work=[[BNR Nieuwsradio|BNR]] |trans-title=Substitution request Robert M. denied |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120418142139/http://www.bnr.nl/programma/juridischezaken/515650-1203/wrakingsverzoek-robert-m.-afgewezen |archivedate=18 April 2012 }} The [[Openbaar Ministerie|prosecution]] demanded a sentence of 20 years' imprisonment,{{cite web|accessdate=26 April 2012 |date=5 April 2012 |url=http://www.startribune.com/world/146286765.html |title=Dutch prosecutors demand 20-year sentence for man accused of molesting dozens of minors |work=[[Star Tribune]] }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} followed by [[Terbeschikkingstelling|Involuntary commitment]] ({{lang-nl|TBS: Ter beschikkingstelling van de Staat}}) for M. and 12 years for Van O. The TBS charge was based on a psychiatric report from the [[Pieter Baan Centre]]. The report was based solely on observation of his behaviour in prison, as M. had refused to cooperate with a psychiatric evaluation. According to the prosecution M. was "cold, calculating, refined and proud of his actions". Although M. pleaded guilty to the abuse, the defense demanded "almost full acquittal", stating that the [[search warrant]] for M. and Van O.'s house (and thus the photo and video evidence from the computers) had not been obtained correctly.{{cite web|language=Dutch|accessdate=17 April 2012|date=16 April 2012|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/11922103/___Huis_onterecht_doorzocht___.html|title=Bijna volledige vrijspraak Robert M. gevraagd (Almost full acquittal requested)|work=[[de Telegraaf]]}} On 20 April 2012, the hearings ended with the "last word" of the defendants (as is customary in Dutch criminal law). M. indicated that he was sorry about his acts and that he should have done more to prevent his acts from happening:{{cite news|accessdate=22 April 2012|date=20 April 2012|work=De Volkskrant|language=Dutch|title=Robert M. in laatste woord: 'Ik had er eigenlijk niet mogen zijn' (Robert M. in last word: I shouldn't have existed)|url=http://www.parool.nl/parool/nl/224/BINNENLAND/article/detail/3243877/2012/04/20/Robert-M-in-laatste-woord-Ik-had-er-eigenlijk-niet-mogen-zijn.dhtml}} {{quote|text=Ik had meer moeten doen. U hebt gelijk, ik had de perfecte mens moeten zijn, want alleen dan had ik deze tragedie kunnen voorkomen.
(English: "I should have done more. You are right, I should have been the perfect man, because only then could I have prevented this tragedy").}} ==Judgement in First Instance== The judgement was given on 21 May 2012. M. was sentenced to 18 years imprisonment, followed by involuntary commitment, while Van O. was sentenced to 6 years imprisonment.{{cite news|work=nu.nl|title=Robert M. krijgt 18 jaar cel en tbs |trans-title=Robert M. gets 18 years imprisonment and involuntary commitment)|url=http://www.nu.nl/binnenland/2815182/robert-m-krijgt-18-jaar-cel-en-tbs.html|accessdate=21 May 2012|date=21 May 2012|language=Dutch}} The search of the house of the defendants (in which the photographic evidence was seized) was deemed admissible and the judges considered the psychiatric evaluation in which M. was [[diminished responsibility]] asserted (a requirement for involuntary commitment) reliable. The diminished responsibility nor his cooperation during the investigation did not result in a lower sentence, due to the nature and level of organization of his crimes. Upon hearing this part of the sentence, M. threw a glass of water at the judge. M. and Van O. were further sentenced to payment of a fine of in total €467,000 euro and €365,000 respectively to the children. Further claims (for material damages to the parents) were deemed "too complicated" to be treated in a criminal court case, but could be claimed in a [[civil lawsuit]]. Non-payment will add 8 days imprisonment per child for M. and Van O. ==Appeal== M.s and Van O. [[appeal]]ed the judgement, which triggered the prosecution to appeal as well (a so-called "vervolg appel") in order to have more possibilities before the [[appellate court]].{{cite news|work=Elsevier |title=Pedofiel Robert Mikelsons gaat in hoger beroep (Pedophile Robert Mikelsons appeals) |url=http://www.elsevier.nl/web/Nieuws/Nederland/340106/Pedofiel-Robert-Mikelsons-gaat-in-hoger-beroep.htm |accessdate=31 May 2012 |date=31 May 2012 |language=Dutch }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite news|url=http://www.nu.nl/binnenland/2825045/in-hoger-beroep-richard-van-o.html|title=OM ook in hoger beroep tegen Richard van O.|date=1 June 2012|accessdate=1 June 2012|work=nu.nl|language=Dutch}} The start of the appeal took place on 15 November 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.parool.nl/parool/nl/4204/ZEDENZAAK-KINDERDAGVERBLIJVEN/article/detail/3288349/2012/07/18/Behandeling-zedenzaak-wordt-voortgezet-in-november.dhtml|title=Behandeling zedenzaak wordt voortgezet in november|work=Novum|date=18 July 2012|accessdate=26 September 2012}} The judges decided to allow a second psychological evaluation center Oldenkotte in [[Rekken]] on the request of Robert M., who indicated his willingness to cooperate.{{cite web|url=http://www.rtl.nl/components/actueel/rtlnieuws/2012/11_november/15/binnenland/nieuw_psychisch_onderzoek_naar_robert_m.xml |title=Nieuw psychisch onderzoek naar Robert M |publisher=RTL Nieuws |date=2012-11-15 |accessdate=2012-11-17 |language=Dutch}} The parents also had the possibility to speak during the trial, as a new law making this right explicit had in the mean time entered into force.{{cite web|author=door Jules Seegers |url=http://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2012/11/15/eerste-zitting-hoger-beroep-robert-m-in-amsterdamse-zedenzaak/ |title=Eerste zitting hoger beroep Robert M. in Amsterdamse zedenzaak |publisher=nrc.nl |date=2012-11-15 |language=Dutch |accessdate=2012-11-17}} On April 26, 2013 the court of appeal sentenced M. to 19 years imprisonment, followed by [[Terbeschikkingstelling|involuntary commitment]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rechtspraak.nl/Actualiteiten/Nieuws/Pages/Roberts-M-veroordeeld-tot-19-jaar-gevangenisstrafenTBSmetdwangverpleging.aspx |title=Roberts M. veroordeeld tot 19 jaar gevangenisstraf en TBS met dwangverpleging |publisher=rechtspraak.nl |date=2013-04-26 |language=Dutch |accessdate=2013-04-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130613012840/http://www.rechtspraak.nl/Actualiteiten/Nieuws/Pages/Roberts-M-veroordeeld-tot-19-jaar-gevangenisstrafenTBSmetdwangverpleging.aspx |archivedate=13 June 2013 }} ==Cassation== M. appealed the judgement to the [[Supreme Court of the Netherlands]] (Hoge Raad) in a [[cassation]] procedure, in which he is represented by Dirk Daamen.{{cite news|url=http://www.nu.nl/binnenland/3493943/robert-m-zet-cassatie.html|title=Robert M. zet cassette door|date=6 June 2013|accessdate=6 Jun 2013|work=[[Nu.nl]]|language=Dutch}} The Hoge Raad dismissed the appeal,{{cite web|url=http://uitspraken.rechtspraak.nl/inziendocument?id=ECLI:NL:HR:2014:2668|title=Decision Hoge Raad, nr ECLI:NL:HR:2014:2668|date=19 September 2014|work=rechtspraak.nl}} in conformation with the advice of its [[Advocate-General]].{{cite web|url=http://uitspraken.rechtspraak.nl/inziendocument?id=ECLI:NL:PHR:2014:632|title=Advice Advocate General to Hoge Raad, nr ECLI:NL:PHR:2014:632|date=19 September 2014|work=rechtspraak.nl}} Due to the length of the procedure before the Supreme Court, which lasted over 16 months, the length of the sentence was reduced by one month to 18 years and 11 months. ==Public reaction== The public in the Netherlands was shocked when the events surfaced.{{cite news|language=Dutch|accessdate=21 April 2012|date=13 December 2010|work=[[Hart van Nederland]]|url=http://www.hartvannederland.nl/nederland/noord-holland/2010/nederland-geschokt-door-ontucht-trio/|title=Nederland geschokt door ontucht-trio (Netherlands shocked by sex crimes trio)}} The public prosecution also stated during the case that the events shocked Dutch society and that it would therefore not be justified to request a lesser sentence than the 20 years demanded.{{cite news|language=Dutch|accessdate=21 April 2012|date=5 April 2012|work=NRC|title=OM eist twintig jaar cel en tbs voor Robert M. (Prosecution demands twenty years imprisonment and involuntary commitment for Robert M.)|author=Lex Boon|url=http://www.nrc.nl/nieuws/2012/04/05/om-eist-20-jaar-cel-voor-robert-m/}} The case has also had effects on male preschool professionals: according to an evaluation by the news agency [[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting|NOS]]{{cite news|language=Dutch|accessdate=21 April 2012|date=1 February 2012|work=NOS|title=Minder mannen in kinderopvang (Fewer men in child care)|author=Jikke Zijlstra|url=http://nos.nl/artikel/336339-minder-mannen-in-kinderopvang.html}} and the ''Belangenvereniging van ouders in de kinderopvang en peuterspeelzalen (Boink)'' (English: Organization for parents in child care and day care),{{cite news|language=Dutch |accessdate=21 April 2012 |date=1 February 2012 |work=NRC |title=Tientallen mannen uit kinderopvang (Tens of men left child care) |url=http://www.nu.nl/binnenland/2730224/tientallen-mannen-kinderopvang.htm }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} tens of men have quit or have been fired as a result of changed public opinion towards men in the field, including negative reactions of parents. ==Worldwide arrests== According to the Amsterdam police, the investigation of leads found on M. computer has led, worldwide, to the arrests of 43 suspected child molesters.{{cite news |title=Arrests in major international child porn investigation |agency=Associated Press |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/arrests-in-major-international-child-porn-investigation/2012/08/04/262afb7e-de41-11e1-8ad1-909913931f71_story.html|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=4 August 2012 |accessdate=4 August 2012}}{{dead link|date=February 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== Judgments regarding M. *{{ECLI|ECLI:NL:RBAMS:2012:BW6148}}, Court of First Instance of Amsterdam (Rechbank Amsterdam) *{{ECLI|ECLI:NL:GHAMS:2013:BZ8885}}, Court of Appeal of Amsterdam (Gerechtshof Amsterdam) *{{ECLI|ECLI:NL:PHR:2014:632}}, Opinion of the Advocate-General of the Supreme Court (Hoge Raad) *{{ECLI|ECLI:NL:HR:2014:2668}}, Supreme Court (Hoge Raad) Judgment regarding Van O. *{{ECLI|ECLI:NL:RBAMS:2012:BW6149}}, Court of First Instance of Amsterdam (Rechbank Amsterdam) [[Category:Day care sexual abuse allegations]] [[Category:Dutch case law]] [[Category:Child pornography]] [[Category:Sexual abuse]] [[Category:Pedophilia]] [[Category:Sex crime trials]] [[Category:2012 in the Netherlands]] [[Category:2012 in case law]]

revision.text:
The '''Bisset Hawkins Medal''' is a triennial award made by the [[Royal College of Physicians]] of London to acknowledge work done in the preceding ten years in advancing sanitary science or promoting public health. It is named after Dr [[Francis Bisset Hawkins]] (1796–1884), a distinguished London physician and is presented after the [[Harveian Oration]].<ref>{{cite web|pmc=2991772|title=Woods and Russell, Hill, and the emergence of medical statistics|publisher=NCBI}}</ref>
The medal, made of gold, was endowed by Captain Edward Wilmot Williams in 1896.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/4778|title=Charles Theodore Williams|publisher=Royal College of Physicians|accessdate=23 September 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017055100/http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/4778|archivedate=17 October 2015|df=}}</ref>
==Medallists== Medallists have been:<ref>{{cite book|title=A History of the Royal College of Physicians of London, Volume 4|first=George Norman|last= Clark|page=1701}}</ref> * 1899: {{ill|James Burn Russell|wd=Q18731097}} <ref>https://archive.org/stream/b24990796_0072/b24990796_0072_djvu.txt</ref> * 1902: [[William Henry Power]]<ref>{{Cite newspaper The Times |articlename=The Royal College of Physicians of London |day_of_week=Saturday |date=2 August 1902 |page_number=11 |issue=36836| }}</ref><ref>https://archive.org/stream/b24990796_0072/b24990796_0072_djvu.txt</ref> * 1905: [[Patrick Manson]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aim25.ac.uk/cgi-bin/vcdf/detail?coll_id=4044&inst_id=37|title= MANSON, Sir Patrick (1844-1922)|publisher= AIM25|accessdate= 23 September 2016}}</ref> * 1908: Sir {{ill|Shirley Forster Murphy|wd=Q18912729}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://livesonline.rcseng.ac.uk/biogs/E002781b.htm|title=Murphy, Sir Shirley Forster (1848 - 1923)|publisher=Royal College of Surgeons|accessdate= 23 September 2016}}</ref> * 1911: [[Clement Dukes]]<ref>{{cite web|jstor=25294903|title=Medical Notes in Parliament}}</ref> * 1914: Sir [[Ronald Ross]]<ref>{{cite web|jstor=1638977|title= Science, Nov 6, 1914}}</ref> ''for his researches on malaria'' * 1917: Sir [[Arthur Newsholme]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/3316|title=Arthur (Sir) Newsholme|publisher=Royal College of Physicians|accessdate= 23 September 2016}}</ref> * 1920: Sir [[William Heaton Hamer]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://opensample.info/reorganisation-of-the-indian-medical-services|title=REORGANISATION OF THE INDIAN MEDICAL SERVICES:|publisher=opensample|accessdate= 23 September 2016}}</ref> * 1923: Sir [[Thomas Morison Legge]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archiveshub.ac.uk/data/gb133-tml.txt|title= Thomas Legge papers|accessdate= 23 September 2016}}</ref> * 1926: Sir [[Ambrose Thomas Stanton]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/4222|title=Ambrose Thomas (Sir) Stanton|publisher=Royal College of Physicians|accessdate= 23 September 2016}}</ref> * 1929: Sir [[Edward Mellanby]]<ref>{{cite journal|title= Science|volume=LXX|issue= 1808|page=188}}</ref> * 1932: [[Thomas Henry Craig Stevenson]]<ref>{{cite journal|title= Science|date= 19 August 1932|page=165}}</ref> * 1935: Sir [[George Newman (doctor)|George Newman]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/3313|title=George (Sir) Newman|publisher=Royal College of Physicians|accessdate= 23 September 2016}}</ref> * 1938: [[Major Greenwood]]<ref>{{cite web|url= http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/1890|title= Major Greenwood|publisher= Royal College of Physicians|accessdate= 23 September 2016|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20151017055333/http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/1890|archivedate= 17 October 2015|df= }}</ref> * 1941: Sir [[Frederick Menzies|Frederick Norton Kay Menzies]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/3066|title=Frederick Norton Kay (Sir) Menzies|publisher=Royal College of Physicians|accessdate= 23 September 2016}}</ref> * 1944: Brigadier [[J. A. Sinton]]<ref name="American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) pp. 214–214">{{cite journal | title=THE ANNUAL MEETING OF THE OPTICAL SOCIETY OF AMERICA | journal=Science | publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) | volume=100 | issue=2593 | date=8 September 1944 | issn=0036-8075 | doi=10.1126/science.100.2593.214 | pages=214–214}}</ref> * 1947: [[Christopher Howard Andrewes]] * 1950: Sir [[William Wilson Jameson]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/2404|title= William Wilson Jameson| publisher=Royal College of Physicians|accessdate= 23 September 2016}}</ref> * 1953: [[William Norman Pickles]]<ref>{{cite web|url= http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/3558|title= William Norman Pickles|publisher= Royal College of Physicians|accessdate= 23 September 2016|deadurl= yes|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20151022193347/http://munksroll.rcplondon.ac.uk/Biography/Details/3558|archivedate= 22 October 2015|df= }}</ref> * 1956: [[Graham Selby Wilson]] * 1959: [[Percy Stocks]] * 1962: Sir [[Richard Doll]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rsbm.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/roybiogmem/56/63.full.pdf|title=Sir Richard Doll CH OBE. 28 October 1912-24 July 2005|publisher= Royal Society| accessdate= 23 September 2016}}</ref> ''for contributions to preventative medicine'' * 1965: Sir [[George Godber|George Edward Godber]] * 1968: {{ill|Charles Montague Fletcher|wd=Q18875434}} * 1971: Sir [[Derrick Dunlop|Derrick Melville Dunlop]] * 1974: {{ill|Patrick Joseph Lawther|wd=Q27924230}} * 1977: Major {{ill|John Alistair Dudgeon|wd=Q18729937}} * 1980: [[Jerry Morris|Jeremy Noah Morris]] * 1983: [[Abraham Manie Adelstein]] * 1986: * 1989: * 1992: * 1995: Sir [[Kenneth Calman|Kenneth Charles Calman]]<ref>{{cite book|title=The International Who's Who 2004}}</ref> * 1998: * 2001: [[Kay-Tee Khaw]]<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.cai.cam.ac.uk/people/professor-kaytee-khaw|title=Professor Kay-Tee Khaw|publisher= Cambridge University|accessdate= 23 September 2016}}</ref> * 2004: [[Michael Gideon Marmot]] * 2007: {{ill|John Britton (epidemiologist)|wd=Q56426545|lt=John Britton}} <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rae.ac.uk/Submissions/ra5a.aspx?subid=3071&type=uoa&id=6|publisher=University of Nottingham|title=UOA 6 - Epidemiology and Public Health RA5a: Research environment and esteem|accessdate= 30 October 2016}}</ref> * 2010: * 2013: {{ill|Nicholas Finer|wd=Q43134951}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Nick_Finer/info|title=Nick Finer|publisher= Researchgate|accessdate= 23 September 2016}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of prizes, medals and awards]] *[[Prizes named after people]]

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
The '''Black Power Movement in Montreal''' in the 1960s was a period of rediscovering black identity through a process of invoking cultural, economic, and political thought amongst blacks. The eruption of political activism during [[Montreal|Montreal's]] [[Quiet Revolution]] as well as the reformation of immigration policies which discriminated against non-white immigrants allowed black communities to publicly express and bring awareness to their struggles with racism. The movement was an integral component of the emerging global challenges to [[imperialism]] during the 1960s and it stemmed from various movements including [[Garveyism]], [[pan-Africanism]], the [[Harlem Renaissance]], [[Rastafari]], and others. Montreal's Black Power movement culminated in the aftermath of the [[Sir George Williams affair|Sir George Williams Affair]]—a student occupation that resulted in an estimated $2 million worth of damages and 97 arrests—which raised concerns of racism worldwide.
== Background == [[File:Union United Church 12.JPG|thumb|The Union United Church, Montreal's Black communities oldest religious institution.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=David|first=Austin|date=Fall 2007|title=All Roads Led to Montreal: Black Power, the Caribbean, and the Black Radical Tradition in Canada|url=|journal=The Journal of African American History|volume=92|pages=|via=Database}}</ref>]] During the early 20th century, Montreal blacks primarily lived in the [[Saint Antoine Street|Saint Antoine]] district, where they were socially excluded and later on evicted to facilitate urban development, forcing them to disperse to other regions of Montreal.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://moishistoiredesnoirs.com/en/about-us/a-bit-about-the-history-of-montreal-blacks/|title=A bit about the history of Montreal Blacks {{!}} Mois histoire des Noirs|website=moishistoiredesnoirs.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-02-20}}</ref> Structural racism was prevalent during the turn of the century and prevented Montreal blacks from obtaining respectable work or adequate housing.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=The Empire Within: Postcolonial Thought and Political Activism in Sixties Montreal|last=Mills|first=Sean|publisher=McGill-Queen's University Press|year=2010|isbn=9780773536951|location=|pages=96}}</ref> Montreal's black community fought racial discrimination through the creation of various social groups such as the [[Union United Church|Union United Church (UUC)]] and the Negro Community Centre (NCC) in 1927.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.urbexplayground.com/urbex/negro-community-center|title=The Negro Community Center|last=Jarold|date=2014-03-17|work=Urbex playground|access-date=2018-02-20|language=en}}</ref> The UUC was originally called the Union Congregational Church of Montreal (UCCM). Founded by American-born railway porters in 1907, the UCCM was a response to the racial discrimination the railway porters had faced at White churches. The UCCM provided the Black community with a space to worship freely without discrimination, and in 1925 the name was changed to the UUC. Led by Reverend Charles Este, the UUC sought to improve the social conditions for the black community through leadership and development. In 1927, clergy members of the UUC founded the NCC, a charitable organisation that also sought to improve the social conditions for the black community. The NCC became a staple in Montreal's black community and contributed to the fight against racial discrimination by promoting black employment, hosting educational programs, and looking after the youth in the black community.<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title=“A Microcosm of the General Struggle”: Black Thought and Activism in Montreal, 1960–1969|last=Hebert|first=Paul|publisher=University of Michigan|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> After the Canadian government's removal of exclusionary immigration policies in the 1950s-1960s, which favoured non-white immigrants, Montreal's black population began to grow. This led to a large migration of West Indian and African blacks to Canada.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/collection/black-history-in-canada/|title=Black History in Canada - The Canadian Encyclopedia|website=www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-02-20}}</ref> These immigrants often came with job skills that advanced the economic standards for Montreal's black population. Despite these advancements, issues of racism and resistance from the black community against these issues persisted. Also, the internationally broadening language of [[dissent]] towards [[colonization]] during the 1960s sparked an increased sense of activism among black intellectuals because it was seen as an opportunity to be heard.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.concordia.ca/cunews/main/stories/2014/02/19/50-years-in-the-fightforracialequality.html|title=50 years in the fight for racial equality|website=www.concordia.ca|access-date=2018-02-20}}</ref> This increased activism was rooted in the idea of [[Black Power]], a slogan coined by [[Stokely Carmichael]] in 1966.<ref name=:1/> During this period, a larger scale [[Black Power movement]] was also occurring in the United States.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Encyclopedia of the African and the African American|last=Appiah|first=Anthony|publisher=Basic Civitas Books|year=1999|isbn=|location=New York|pages=262}}</ref> Black intellectuals in Montreal drew from the analyses of race and imperialism formulated by black intellectuals in the United States. The ideas of [[Malcolm X]], [[Martin Luther King Jr.|Martin Luther king]], and [[Stokely Carmichael]] inspired the Black Power movement in Montreal and the [[Assassination of Martin Luther King Jr.|assassination of Martin Luther King]] sparked protest in Montreal.<ref name=fear>{{Cite book|title=Fear of a Black Nation|last=David|first=Austin|publisher=Between the Lines|year=2013|isbn=9781771130110|location=Toronto|pages=1–36}}</ref> Locally in Montreal, many social groups expressing anti-colonial and anti-imperialist ideas formed during the Quiet Revolution. Among these groups were French Canadians, feminist groups, and workers rights groups. These various groups contributed to and borrowed from the circulating language of dissent in Montreal as well as internationally during this period. Montreal's Black Power Movement was one of the actors in the Quiet Revolution and the struggles experienced by blacks resonated with other groups during the time.<ref name=:1/> Internationally, Montreal's Black Power movement was inspired by third world liberation struggles. The liberation of India in 1947, Ghana and Malaya in 1957, and Algeria from French colonialism in 1962 inspired anti-colonial ideas in Montreal. Also, The Cuban revolution inspired anti-colonial ideas in Montreal because Cuba's dissolution of trading ties with the United States demonstrated that a small nation could stand against a large imperial power. Black intellectuals linked institutional racism to imperial oppression and the Cuban revolution symbolized freedom from this oppression.<ref name=fear/>
== Montreal in the 1960s ==
=== Negro Citizenship Association === The Negro Citizenship Association (NCA) was founded in 1951 by Donald William Moore.<ref name=":9" /> The NCA was a civil rights organisation that initially opposed Canada's exclusionary immigration policies which favoured non-white immigrants.<ref name=":9">{{Cite news|url=https://www.toronto.ca/city-government/accountability-operations-customer-service/access-city-information-or-records/city-of-toronto-archives/whats-online/web-exhibits/caribbean-connection-one-mans-crusade/|title=Caribbean Connection: One Man's Crusade|last=Toronto|first=City of|date=2017-11-23|work=City of Toronto|access-date=2018-03-30|language=en-CA}}</ref> After [[World War II]], Britain encouraged Caribbean immigration to aid post-war recovery, however this inflow was restricted in the 1950s. Britain's tightening of immigration policies resulted in the Caribbean government urging Canada to allow Caribbean immigrants into the country.<ref name=":10" /> The NCA worked with the Caribbean government to publicly reveal and change Canada's exclusionary immigration policies. This united effort led to the West Indian Domestic scheme, which provided Caribbean females with the opportunity to apply for temporary or permanent residency in Canada after a year of domestic work.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=David|first=Austin|date=Fall 2007|title=ALL ROADS LED TO MONTREAL: BLACK POWER, THE CARIBBEAN, THE BLACK RADICAL TRADITION IN CANADA.|url=http://web.b.ebscohost.com/ehost/detail/detail?vid=0&sid=f021b291-22e4-439c-9ced-51c88cbc79c1%40pdc-v-sessmgr01&bdata=JnNpdGU9ZWhvc3QtbGl2ZQ%3d%3d#AN=28323812&db=ahl|journal=Journal of African American History|volume=92|pages=516–539|via=Western Libraries}}</ref> Canada's exclusionary immigration policy continued to unravel and eventually became a point system in the [[Immigration Act, 1976|Immigration Act, 1967]].<ref name=:1/> By the 1960s, black activism was becoming more vocal in Montreal and the black community was beginning to take a stronger stand against racism.<ref name=":5"/> The influx of Caribbean students following the shift in immigration policies introduced anti-colonial ideas into Montreal's black community. These new ideas sometimes clashed with the more civil ideas of the established black community. By 1965, the NCA was beginning to take action against racism through their journal ''Expression.'' ''Expression'' typically published controversial, assertive articles advocating for the black community and denouncing racism. ''Expression'' also sought a strengthening of anti-discrimination legislation in Montreal. Following the assassination of Martin Luther King in 1968, ''Expression'' published an article advocating for violence in black activism onwards.<ref name=:1/>
=== Caribbean Conference Committee === The Caribbean Conference Committee (CCC) was formed in 1965 by a group of Caribbean immigrants who sought to provide a platform for intellectuals to discuss anti-colonial ideas and formulate political as well as social change.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/sir-george-williams-affair/|title=Sir George Williams Affair|last=Lambert|first=Maude-Emmanuelle|work=The Canadian Encyclopedia|access-date=2018-02-20|language=en}}</ref> Many Caribbean immigrants intended to return to the Caribbean and become politically active after earning an education, funds, or both in Canada. The common aspiration to fight colonialism in the Caribbean inspired a group of Caribbean men and women to form the CCC. Among this group were [[Alphonso Theodore Roberts|Alfie Roberts]], [[Rosie Douglas]], and [[Anne Cools]]. The committee held multiple conferences that featured influential activists from around the globe such as [[George Lamming]] and [[C. L. R. James|C.L.R James]]. The committee discussed and formulated political and social change in the Caribbean, which consequently inspired ideas of change in the local setting of Montreal.<ref name=:1/> The Caribbean Conference Committee separated in 1967 when some members dispersed, however the name of the organisation was changed to the Canadian Conference Committee (CCC) which represented a shift in Caribbean focus to Canada as their home.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/144083837|title=The Blacks in Canada : a history|last=Winks|first=Robin|date=|publisher=McGill-Queen's University Press|year=1971|isbn=0773516328|edition= 2nd|location=Montreal, Que.|pages=405|oclc=144083837}}</ref> Caribbean students became less concerned with Caribbean decolonization and more interested in domestic racial issues. In 1968, the assassination of [[Martin Luther King Jr.]] resulted in a turn to radicalism for some black activists.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.history.com/topics/black-history/martin-luther-king-jr-assassination|title=Martin Luther King Jr. Assassination - Black History - HISTORY.com|website=HISTORY.com|access-date=2018-02-21}}</ref> King advocated for unity amongst all races, however some black activists began to see violence and separation from Whites as the only solution to racial issues in the wake of his death, resulting in a shift to the Black Power movement. Montreal's black population voiced their rage through protests as well as two [[conference]]s.<ref name=:1/> The first conference was a three-day event from October 4 to 6, 1968, held at Sir George Williams University. The conference was organized by black activists seeking racial equality through civil means. Inspired by the Caribbean Conference Committee and titled the ''Black People in Canada Conference'', It addressed the local, daily concerns of Montreal's black population and featured [[Howard McCurdy]], a professor at the University of Windsor, who emphasized the importance for blacks to understand their identity and have a voice.<ref name=:1/> The conference also sought to reconcile class divide and conflict amongst Montreal Blacks, particularly between the Caribbean immigrants and established black Canadians. The second conference was a four-day event from October 11 to 14, 1968, held at McGill and it was titled ''The Congress of Black Writers''. The most prominent speech at this event was [[Stokely Carmichael|Stokely Carmichael's]], which amassed a crowd of over 2000 people and was centered around [[Black Power]] as well as the idea that blacks should liberate themselves internationally through revolution.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bscportal.wordpress.com/history-of-conferences-in-the-black-community-of-montreal/|title=History of Conferences in the Black Community of Montreal|date=2015-08-30|work=BLACK STUDIES CENTER PORTAL|access-date=2018-02-21|language=en-US}}</ref> Carmichael asserted that revolution was necessary to rebuild the social system that had previously oppressed blacks internationally through [[slavery]] and [[colonization]]. The majority of the attendance at this second committee was of a younger demographic and the radical ideas expressed conflicted with the more civil ideas of the ''Black People in Canada Conference''.<ref name=fear/>
=== Sir George Williams Affair === {{main|Sir George Williams Affair}} Montreal's Black Power Movement culminated with the [[Sir George Williams affair|Sir George Williams Affair]] which ended on February 11, 1969. In response to the [[Sir George Williams University|Sir George William's University]] committee's failure to act on six accusations of racially prejudiced grading against Professor Perry Anderson, roughly 200 demonstrators—mostly White—peacefully occupied the computer centre at the school. After 14 days, negotiations went astray and the [[Occupation (protest)|occupation]] ended in a fire, roughly $2 million in damages and 97 arrests.<ref name=:4/> The student occupation was the manifestation of the [[Black Power]] movement in Montreal and an international display of the daily adversities and discrimination faced by the black community. Among the occupants arrested were [[Rosie Douglas]] and [[Anne Cools]], who were seen as the leaders of the occupation by authorities.<ref name=:1/> Other occupants lost employment opportunities in Canada, and some had to migrate back to the Caribbean without completing their education.<ref name=fear/> While the fire occurred, some White spectators chanted "Let the niggers burn."<ref name=:1/> In a 1971 McGill Free Press article, [[Tim Hector]] denounced the priority given to the damaged computers over the students lives. Nonetheless, Hector also recognized the occupation as a declaration of black presence in Montreal society.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=David|first=Austin|date=Fall 2007|title=ALL ROADS LED TO MONTREAL: BLACK POWER, THE CARIBBEAN, THE BLACK RADICAL TRADITION IN CANADA.|url=|journal=Journal of African American History|volume=92|pages=|via=}}</ref> Although many Anglophone students refused to support the protestors after the computer damages the protestors began to receive support from some francophone groups. The [[Confédération des syndicats nationaux]] (CSN), Montreal's second largest labour union, criticized the media for focusing on the material losses of the occupation instead of the racial issues in Canada. Francophone intellectuals had previously neglected the black community in Montreal, however the events of the occupation changed their views on race in the city.<ref name=:1/> The Sir George Williams Affair brought the black community closer together and in October 1969, members of Montreal's black community occupied the [[Queen Elizabeth Hotel]] during an [[African Studies Association]] (ASA) session with the Canadian African Studies Association. Many of these occupants had participated in the Sir George Williams Affair and they teamed up with the African Heritage Studies Association, founded by [[John Henrik Clarke]], to denounce the lack of Black representation within the ASA. This occupation was a demonstration of the increased militancy within the Black community sparked by the Sir George Williams Affair.<ref name=fear/> Also, the occupation inspired the creation of the Thursday Night Rally within the black community. The Thursday Night Rally was a weekly meeting initially created to discuss news concerning the arrests of the Sir George Williams Affair. The meetings grew and eventually became a platform for communal discussions on racism in Montreal. The meetings would often feature historian Roy States, screen films about the Black struggle, and discuss Africa as well as South America.<ref name=:1/>
== Aftermath == [[File:TnT St. Augustine UWI Campus.jpg|thumb|The University of West Indies St. Augustine Campus, where Daniel Roland Michener was denied access following the Sir George Williams occupation. By Grueslayer - Own work, CC BY-SA 4.0, <nowiki>https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=36254377</nowiki><ref>{{Cite book|title=The Empire Within: Postcolonial Thought and Political Activism in Sixties Montreal|last=Mills|first=Sean|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=105}}</ref>]] The inaction of the university committee and the outcome of the Sir George Williams occupation publicly displayed the racial tensions in Canada. In Montreal, the Sir George Williams affair revealed the covert racism in Canadian society and brought the Black community closer together. Although francophone intellectuals had previously ignored Montreal's black population, they showed support for the black community after the events and denounced [[institutional racism]].<ref name=":1" /> The events inspired black activists to begin challenging imperialism through the entire community rather than solely through the university system. New organizations were formed such as the [https://liguedesnoirs.org/en/ Black Coalition of Quebec], a Human Rights organization. The black community also created a controversial newspaper titled "Uhuru," which became a venue for black activism and recognized the colonization of blacks as well as other groups.<ref name=":1"/> The events of the Sir George William occupation also sparked anger in the [[Caribbean]], where [[Roland Michener]] was denied entrance into the [[University of the West Indies]] on his "Good-will tour" in 1969.<ref name=":5" /> The arrest of 10 Trinidadian students during the occupation sparked protest in the [[West Indies]], and the protests eventually transformed into demonstrations against the government and began a Black Power movement in [[Trinidad and Tobago|Trinidad]].<ref name="fear" /> Following these events, Trinidad's local military nearly [[Deposition (politics)|deposed]] the government.<ref name="fear" /> [[Alphonso Theodore Roberts|Alfie Roberts]], a black intellectual, believed the occupation affirmed the presence of blacks in Montreal and corresponded with the local [[Labor unrest|labour unrest]] of the 1960s<ref name=":1" /> The Sir George Williams occupation triggered a Black Renaissance in Montreal and demonstrated the black communities refusal of continued discrimination.
== Criticisms == Similar to other social movements during the Quiet Revolution, Montreal's Black Power movement had its own contradictions. The Black Power movement drew on an idea of black [[masculinity]], which was [[militant]] and exclusionary.<ref name=":5"/> At ''The Congress of Black Writers,'' [[Stokely Carmichael]] advocated for political change through violence, which received mixed reactions from members of the black community. Also, the movement used gendered language which excluded women. Defined as a "struggle for manhood," the Black Power movement was a call to black men and ignored the role of women. Black women felt the movement was hypocritical and devalued them- some believing they were oppressed by black men just as black men were oppressed by Whites.<ref name=":1"/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Montreal History}}
[[Category:Black Power|Montreal]] [[Category:Political history of Quebec]] [[Category:Race in Canada]] [[Category:1960s in Montreal]] [[Category:African and Black nationalism in North America|Montreal]]

{{one source|date=November 2016}} '''CLEAPSS''' is an advisory service providing support in [[science]] and [[technology]] for a consortium of [[local authorities]] and their schools including establishments for pupils with [[special needs]].<ref>{{cite web|title=About CLEAPSS|url=http://www.cleapss.org.uk/about-cleapss|accessdate=1 November 2016}}</ref>
[[Independent school]]s, post-16 colleges, teacher training establishments, curriculum developers and others can apply for associate membership. CLEAPSS offers help from nursery education through to A-level studies or equivalent.
CLEAPSS first started in 1963 as '''CLEAPSE''' (Consortium of Local Education Authorities for the Provision of Science Equipment). In 1988 the name was changed to CLEAPSS ('''Consortium of Local Education Authorities for the Provision of Science Services''') to reflect a change of emphasis from equipment to a range of services. Since then, [[Local Education Authorities]] became Local Authorities (LAs) and CLEAPSS' services expanded to include [[D&T]], so CLEAPSS was registered as a [[Trade Mark]]. CLEAPSS is now simply a name and not an acronym.
CLEAPSS is based at the [[Brunel University]] Science Park in [[Uxbridge]].
== People served == CLEAPSS serves:<ref>{{cite web|title=About CLEAPSS|url=http://www.cleapss.org.uk/about-cleapss|accessdate=1 November 2016}}</ref>
* teachers (including head teachers), * technicians, * science advisers/inspectors/consultants, * teacher trainers, * health and safety advisers, * architects (working for subscribers), * other local authority officers, * school governors.
== Areas covered == CLEAPSS covers:<ref>{{cite web|title=About CLEAPSS|url=http://www.cleapss.org.uk/about-cleapss|accessdate=1 November 2016}}</ref>
* [[health and safety]] including model [[risk assessment]]s, * chemicals, living organisms, equipment, * sources of resources, * laboratory design, facilities and fittings, * technicians and their jobs, * D&T facilities and fittings.
CLEAPSS provides support for a consortium of local authorities. It is controlled by its members, which currently include all LAs throughout the British Isles (not Scotland) (100% of those eligible).
== Associate members == CLEAPSS has around 2,000 associate members, i.e.:<ref>{{cite web|title=About CLEAPSS|url=http://www.cleapss.org.uk/about-cleapss|accessdate=1 November 2016}}</ref>
* foundation and voluntary-aided schools (where not a member via a local authority), * independent schools, * incorporated colleges, * teacher-training establishments and science learning centres, * overseas institutions, * field centres, museums, etc, * curriculum developers.
== Services provided == CLEAPSS provides:<ref>{{cite web|title=About CLEAPSS|url=http://www.cleapss.org.uk/about-cleapss|accessdate=1 November 2016}}</ref>
* termly newsletters for primary and secondary schools, * a wide range of free publications, * model risk assessments, * special risk assessments, * low-cost training courses for technicians, teachers and local authority officers, * a telephone helpline which takes nearly 7,000 calls per year, * a monitoring service, e.g. for [[Mercury poisoning|mercury spills]], * evaluations of equipment, * advice on repairs, * a H&S / Review service for publishers, exam. boards and other organisations producing teaching resources.
== See also == {{Portal|Science|Education}} * [[Education in the UK]] * [[Science education]] {{Clear}}
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{Official website|science.cleapss.org.uk/}}
[[Category:Science education]] [[Category:Education advocacy groups]]
