revision.comment: /* Further reading */adding [[Category:Former polities of the Cold War]] per [[Template_talk:Infobox_country#Lost_categorization|this discussion]] based on [[WP:TCAT]] issues
revision.text:
{{Infobox former country |native_name = ''Royaume du Burundi'' ([[French language|French]]) |conventional_long_name = Kingdom of Burundi |common_name = Burundi |continent = Africa |region = Eastern Africa |country = Burundi |era = Cold War |status = {{small|Independent state (17th century–1890)
Part of [[German East Africa]] (1890–1916)
Part of [[Ruanda-Urundi]] (1916–1962)
Independent state (1962–1966)}} |status_text = |empire = Belgium |government_type = [[Monarchy]] |year_start = 17th century |year_end = 1966 |event_start = |date_start = |event_end = Republic |life_span = 1680–1966 |date_end = November 28 |event1 = [[German East Africa]] |date_event1 = July 1, 1890 |event2 = [[Ruanda-Urundi]] |date_event2 = July 20, 1922 |event3 = Autonomy |date_event3 = December 21, 1961 |event4 = Independence |date_event4 = July 1, 1962 |event_pre = |date_pre = |event_post = |date_post = |p1 = |flag_p1 = |p2 = |flag_p2 = |s1 = Republic of Burundi |flag_s1 = Flag_of_Burundi_(1962-1966).svg |s2 = |flag_s2 = |image_flag = Flag_of_Burundi_(1962-1966).svg |flag = |flag_type = |image_coat = Coat of arms of the Kingdom of Burundi.svg |symbol = |symbol_type = |image_map = LocationBurundi.svg |image_map_alt = |image_map_caption = Territory of the Kingdom of Burundi in 1966. |capital = [[Gitega]]
[[Bujumbura]] |capital_exile = |national_motto = ''Imana, Umwan, Uburundi''
''Dieu, le Roi et le Burundi''
{{small|"God, the King and Burundi"}} |national_anthem = ''[[Burundi bwacu]] (Our Burundi)'' |common_languages = [[Kirundi]], [[French language|French]] |leader1 = [[Ntare I]] {{small|(first)}} |leader2 = [[Ntare V of Burundi|Ntare V]] {{small|(last)}} |year_leader1 = 1680–1709 |year_leader2 = 1966 |title_leader = ''[[List of Kings of Burundi|Mwami]]'' |deputy1 = [[Joseph Cimpaye]] {{small|(first)}} |deputy2 = [[Michel Micombero]] {{small|(last)}} |year_deputy1 = 1961 |year_deputy2 = 1966 |title_deputy = [[Prime Minister of Burundi|Prime Minister]] |stat_year1 = 1966 |stat_area1 = 27834 |stat_pop1 = 3275000 |footnotes = |today={{flag|Burundi}}}} The '''Kingdom of Burundi''' ({{lang-fr|Royaume du Burundi}}) or '''Kingdom of Urundi''' (''Royaume d'Urundi'') was a [[polity]] ruled by a [[traditional authority|traditional monarch]] in modern-day [[Burundi|Republic of Burundi]] in the [[African Great Lakes|Great Lakes region]] of [[East Africa]]. The kingdom, majority ethnic [[Hutu]], was ruled by a monarch from the [[Tutsi|Tutsi ethnic group]] with the title of ''[[mwami]]''. Created in the 17th century, the kingdom was preserved under [[Western European colonialism and colonization|European colonial rule]] in the late 19th and early 20th century and was an independent state between 1962 and 1966. ==History== The date of the foundation of the Kingdom of Burundi is unknown but probably dates back to the 17th century when the [[Tutsi|Tutsi ethnic group]] gained dominance over the larger [[Hutu|ethnic Hutu]] population of the region. Under ''mwami'' [[Ntare I]] ({{Reign}}1675–1705), the kingdom expanded and annexed a number of surrounding polities.{{cite encyclopedia |encyclopedia= [[Encyclopædia Britannica]] |title= Kingdom of Burundi |url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Kingdom-of-Burundi |access-date= 15 October 2016 |edition= Online}} Although ruled by the ''mwami'', the kingdom was extensively decentralised and local sub-rulers had wide independence. Before the arrival of European colonists, succession struggles were also common. In 1890, Burundi became part of the [[German colonial empire]] as part of [[German East Africa]] but was not effectively occupied or controlled by the colonial power. During [[World War I]], Belgian troops from the neighbouring [[Belgian Congo]] invaded the region and occupied it. The Belgians were awarded Burundi, together with the neighbouring [[Kingdom of Rwanda]], as an [[League of Nations mandates|international mandate]] by the [[League of Nations]]. The Belgians, however, preserved many of the kingdom's institutions intact. Whereas the similar Rwandan monarchy [[Rwandan Revolution|was abolished in a revolution]] between 1959 and 1961, the Burundian monarchy succeeded in surviving into the post-colonial period. In 1962, the Kingdom of Burundi regained its independence as a [[constitutional monarchy]] in which the ''mwami'' held executive power and legislative power was given to the parliament.{{cite web|title= Burundi: Fall of the Monarchy (1962 - 1966)|url=https://eisa.org.za/wep/buroverview4.htm|publisher=African Democracy Encyclopaedia Project|accessdate=15 October 2016}} Ethnic violence between the Hutu majority and the Tutsi minority rose, however, between 1963 and 1965 and culminated with a [[1965 Burundian coup d'état|failed coup d'état]] against the monarchy of [[Mwambutsa IV Bangiriceng of Burundi|Mwambutsa IV]] in 1965. Mwambutsa's son, [[Ntare V of Burundi|Ntare V]], deposed his father in a [[July 1966 Burundian coup d'état|July 1966 coup d'état]], but was himself ousted from power in a [[November 1966 Burundian coup d'état|November 1966 coup d'état]] by his Prime Minister, [[Michel Micombero]], who abolished the monarchy. ==Monarchs== {{main|List of Kings of Burundi}} ==Legacy== Most members of the royal house live in exile in [[France]] today. In the 2005 elections, [[Princess Esther Kamatari]] ran for president for the [[Abahuza|Party for the Restoration of Monarchy and Dialogue in Burundi]] (Abahuza). Supporters believe that a restoration of a [[constitutional monarchy]] could help to ease the country's ethnic tensions.{{cite news|title=Pro-monarchy party gets green light in Burundi|agency=Panapress|date=21 September 2004|url=http://www.panapress.com/Pro-monarchy-party-gets-green-light-in-Burundi--13-555192-17-lang2-index.html|accessdate=15 October 2016}} The flag of the kingdom contained a ''[[karyenda]]'' in the center as a symbol of royal authority.''Guide to the Flags of the World'' by Mauro Talocci, revised and updated by Whitney Smith ({{ISBN|0-688-01141-1}}), p. 153. ==See also== *[[History of Burundi]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book|last=Gahama|first=Joseph|title=Le Burundi sous administration belge: La periode du mandat, 1919-1939|publisher=Karthala|location=Paris|year=1983|isbn=9782865370894}} {{Burundi topics}} {{Former Monarchies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Burundian Monarchy}} [[Category:Burundian monarchy]] [[Category:Former monarchies of Africa]] [[Category:1860 establishments in Africa]] [[Category:1966 disestablishments in Africa]] [[Category:States and territories established in 1860]] [[Category:States and territories disestablished in 1966]] [[Category:17th-century establishments in Africa]] [[Category:1960s disestablishments in Burundi]] [[Category:Former polities of the Cold War]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox book | | name = Lavengro | title_orig = | translator = | image = Lavengro 1st ed.jpg | caption = First edition title page | author = [[George Borrow]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | series = | genre = Autobiographical novel | publisher = [[John Murray (publisher)|John Murray]] | release_date = 1851 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print (hardback) | pages = | preceded_by = | followed_by = [[The Romany Rye]] }} '''''Lavengro: The Scholar, the Gypsy, the Priest''''' (1851) is a work by [[George Borrow]], falling somewhere between the genres of memoir and novel, which has long been considered a classic of 19th-century English literature. According to the author ''lav-engro'' is a [[Romani language|Romany]] word meaning "word master".George Borrow ''Lavengro'' (London: John Murray, 1851) p. 108. The historian [[G. M. Trevelyan]] called it "a book that breathes the spirit of that period of strong and eccentric characters".George M. Trevelyan ''British History in the Nineteenth Century and After (1782–1919)'' (London: Longmans, Green, 1941) p. 171. Its protagonist, whose name is George, is born the son of an officer in a militia regiment and is brought up in various barrack towns in England, Scotland and Ireland. After serving an apprenticeship to a lawyer he moves to London and becomes a [[Grub Street]] hack, an occupation which gives him ample opportunities to observe London low-life. Finally he takes to the road as a tinker. At various points through the book he associates with Romany travellers, of whom he gives memorable and generally sympathetic pen-portraits. ''Lavengro'' was followed by a sequel, ''[[The Romany Rye]]''. However, neither of the two books are self-contained. Rather, ''Lavengro'' ends abruptly with chapter 100, and carries on directly in ''The Romany Rye''. Thus both need to be read together, in order. Borrow began work on ''Lavengro'' in 1842 and had written most of it by the end of 1843, but progress was then interrupted by a tour of eastern Europe and by bouts of ill-health, physical and mental.Herbert Jenkins ''The Life of George Borrow'' (London: John Murray, 1912) p. 366 He certainly intended the book to be an autobiography when he first set to work, and while writing it he more than once called it his Life in letters to his publisher, [[John Murray (publisher)|John Murray]]. In 1848 Murray advertised it as a forthcoming work to be called ''Lavengro, an Autobiography''.Herbert Jenkins ''The Life of George Borrow'' (London: John Murray, 1912) pp. 366, 388 However the version Borrow finally delivered had been reshaped into an autobiographical novel whose fictional episodes are inextricably intertwined with genuine memoir.[[Walter Starkie]], in his introduction to the Everyman edition, says, "We should approach ''Lavengro-Romany Rye'' as we do [[James Joyce]]'s autobiographical novel ''[[A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man]]''." Only the "scholar" in the book's subtitle refers to Borrow."Should you imagine that these three form one, permit me to assure you that you are very much mistaken." (Author's Preface to the First Edition) The first edition had a print-run of only 3000 copies; it was such a slow seller that no reprint was needed until 1872.George A. Stephen ''Borrow House Museum: A Brief Account of the Life of George Borrow and his Norwich Home, with a Bibliography'' (Norwich: Norwich Public Libraries Committee, 1927) p. 18; Herbert Jenkins ''The Life of George Borrow'' (London: John Murray, 1912) p. 390. Nor was it a critical success, reviewers being annoyed by the mix of fact and fiction and finding the treatment of Romany life insufficiently quaint. ''[[Blackwood's Magazine]]'' brought in a typical verdict:
We looked for some new revelations on the subjects of fortune-telling, hocus-pocus, and glamour. Lavengro, with his three attributes like those of [[Vishnu]], might possibly be the Grand [[Cacique|Cazique]], the supreme prince of the nation of tinkers! We have read the book, and we are disappointed. The performance bears no adequate relation to the promise…The adventures, though interesting in their way, neither bear the impress of the stamp of truth, nor are they so arranged as to make the work valuable, if we consider it in the light of fiction.''Blackwood's Magazine'' vol. 69, p. 323.
After Borrow's death in 1881 ''Lavengro'' began to find a new audience and enthusiastic praise from critics. [[Theodore Watts-Dunton|Theodore Watts]], in an introduction to the 1893 edition, declared that "There are passages in ''Lavengro'' which are unsurpassed in the prose literature of England".George Borrow ''Lavengro'' (London: Ward, Lock, Bowden, 1893) p. vii. This edition started a run of reprints which produced one or more almost every year for 60 years. ''Lavengro'' was included in the [[Oxford University Press]] [[Oxford World's Classics|World's Classics]] series in 1904, and in [[Everyman's Library]] in 1906.[http://copac.ac.uk/search?au=borrow&ti=lavengro&sort-order=date Catalogue entry] at [[Copac]]. == Notes == {{reflist}} == External links == {{wikisource}} '''Full-text online editions''' * [http://ebooks.adelaide.edu.au/b/borrow/george/lavengro/index.html eBooks@Adelaide] * [http://www.fullbooks.com/Lavengro.html FullBooks] * [https://archive.org/stream/lavengroscholar07borrgoog/lavengroscholar07borrgoog_djvu.txt Internet Archive] * [http://www.ebooksread.com/authors-eng/george-borrow/lavengro-the-scholar-the-gypsy-the-priest-254.shtml www.ebooksread.com] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080907115306/http://www.topboookz.com/G/George_Borrow/Lavengro/read_book.html Topboookz] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=K5UQAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_v2_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q=&f=false Google Books] '''Criticism''' * [http://www.acampbell.ukfsn.org/bookreviews/r/borrow.html Review] of ''Lavengro'' and ''[[The Romany Rye]]'' by [[Anthony Campbell (physician)|Anthony Campbell]] [[Category:1851 British novels]] [[Category:English novels]] [[Category:British autobiographical novels]] [[Category:Fictional representations of Romani people]]

revision.comment: /* The club */[[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], replaced: clientelle → clientele
revision.text:
{{coord|45.494548|N|73.57618|W|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Infobox company | name = Montefiore Club | logo = Montefoire Club - logo 01.jpg | caption = | type = Private club | genre = [[Judaism|Jewish]] | fate = Closed | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = 1880 | founder = | defunct = 2010 | location_city = [[Montreal]] | location_country = [[Canada]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = | industry = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = | footnotes = | intl = }} The '''Montefiore Club''' was a private social and business association, catering to the [[Jewish people|Jewish]] community, located in [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], [[Canada]].[http://www.manilaclub.org/about/name-montefiore-club-country-canada.html Montefiore Club] ==History== [[File:Montefoire Club in May 2015 - 02.JPG|thumbnail|left|Sign above door]] Founded in 1880, the club was originally called the "Montefiore Social and Dramatic Club",{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_cazAAAAIAAJ|title=Mr. Sam: the life and times of Samuel Bronfman|last=Marrus|first=Michael Robert|date=1991-01-01|publisher=Penguin Books Canada|isbn=9780670834303|language=en}} named for [[Moses Montefiore|Sir Moses Haim Montefiore]], the [[United Kingdom|British]]-Jewish [[philanthropist]].{{cite book |title=From the ghetto to the Main : the story of the Jews of Montreal |last=King |first=Joe |authorlink=Joe King (writer) |author2=Johanne Schumann |year=2001 |publisher=Montreal Jewish Publication Society |location= Montreal|isbn= |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} It was established by 11 people, all quite young, with ages ranging from 15 to 23,[http://www.cjnews.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=19666&Itemid=86 The Canadian Jewish News - Montefiore Club closing doors after 130 years] as a social club for young Jewish people. It held [[fundraising]] [[Ball (dance)|ball]]s to help Jewish [[refugee]]s, and [[Play (theatre)|play]]s that were produced to fund welfare programs for [[immigrant]]s.{{cite book |title=SHUCHAT, The Gate of Heaven: The Story of the Congregation Shaar Hashomayim of Montreal, 1846-1996 |last=Shuchat |first=Wilfred |authorlink=Wilfred Shuchat|year=2002 |publisher= CANADIAN HISTORICAL REVIEW, 83, Part 1 (2002): 9|location= |isbn= |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} Later renamed the "Montefoire Club", and modelled on [[upper class]] [[gentlemen's club]]s of [[London]],{{cite book |title=Samuel Bronfman : the life and times of Seagram's Mr. Sam |last=Marrus |first= Michael|authorlink=Michael Robert Marrus |year=1991 |publisher= University Press of New England for Brandeis University Press|location= Hanover |isbn= |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} it functioned as a private social and business association,Taking root: the origins of the Canadian Jewish community By Gerald J. J. Tulchinsky https://books.google.com/books?id=7tMCamkUKuQC catering to members of the [[Jewish people|Jewish]] community.[http://www.wertheimer.info/family/GRAMPS/Birnbaum/plc/6/0/b426d66270228490706.html Birnbaum-Grobstein family database - Places - Montefiore Club, Montreal, Quebec, Canada]{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Among its members, were "well-to-do" members of the Jewish community, who were excluded from [[elite]] [[English Canadian|Anglophone]] clubs such as the St. James and the Mount Royal.{{cite book |title=Canada's Jews : a people's journey |last=Tulchinsky |first=Gerald |authorlink=Gerald J J Tulchinsky |year= 2008|publisher=University of Toronto Press |location=Toronto : Buffalo |isbn= |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} In the early 1990s, the club had more than 600 paying members. In the mid-1990s, $500,000 was spent on renovations to the building. In 2005, after experiencing a decline in membership, new policies were introduced: *Annual fees were reduced *Women were admitted as full members *The [[dress code]] was relaxed *New activities were introduced including luncheon speakers and wine workshops In its final years, the building was used frequently by [[Concordia University (Quebec)|Concordia University]], usually for social events. In the summer of 2010, after experiencing years of financial difficulties, the club closed. ==The club== To obtain membership, a contribution to the life of Montreal's Jewish community was prerequisite.{{cite book |title=Father, son and CIA |last=Weinstein |first=Harvey |authorlink=Harvey Weinstein |year= 1990 |publisher=Goodread Biographies |location=Halifax, N.S. |isbn= |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} The location of the Montefoire Club itself changed locations three times, the last being its 1195 [[Guy Street]] address, where it remained for 104 years, until its closure. The Guy Street location displayed no sign, with only a green canopy identifying it. The building is a large, three-storey [[Victorian architecture|Victorian]] greystone. The Guy Street location had a luxurious interior, with high ceilings, and a lobby built with large [[oak]] beams in a [[Architecture of the Netherlands|Dutch style]]. The rooms were carpeted, with deep-cusioned chairs and sofas, and walls of fine carved wood. Card rooms were located on the second floor, with bedrooms on the third floor that were made available on a temporary basis for members. Wives and children were forbidden access to the second and third floors.https://books.google.com/books?id=_Wh-2gcQl6kC&pg=PA174 Never Climbed His Mountain By Julian Gladstone The club was open seven days a week, and often rented out its facilities for community events. The cuisine was considered among the finest in the city, and although having a Jewish clientele, the club was never [[kosher]].{{cite book |title=Maintaining consensus : the Canadian Jewish polity in the postwar world |last=Elazar |first=Daniel Judah |authorlink=Daniel Judah Elazar |author2=Harold J Waller |year= 1990|publisher=University Press of America ; [Jerusalem] : Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs |location=Lanham |isbn= |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} ==Notable meetings== Throughout its history, the club was as a venue for many notable meetings involving prominent members of the Jewish community. *The establishment of the forerunner of the [[Federation CJA]]. *The planning of the [[Jewish General Hospital]]. *A meeting of Canadian Jewish leaders was convened by [[Samuel Bronfman]] and [[Sam Steinberg]] during the [[Six-Day War]]. In that single afternoon, $13 million was raised.{{cite book |title=Leo: A Life |last=Kolber |first=Leo |author2=MacDonald, L. Ian |year=2006|publisher=McGill Queens Univ Pr |location=Ontario |isbn= |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} ==Closure== [[File:Montefoire Club in May 2015 - 01.JPG|thumbnail|Montefoir Club in 2015]] In the summer of 2010, after operating for 130 years, and with only 72 paying members,[http://www.jewpi.com/montefiore-club-closing-doors-after-130-years/ Montefiore Club closing doors after 130 years | JewPI.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100916034630/http://www.jewpi.com/montefiore-club-closing-doors-after-130-years/ |date=2010-09-16 }} the club closed. It had been experiencing financial difficulties, and had insufficient membership to remain open. At the time of its closure, the club had used all of its financial reserves, and was operating at a deficit of approximately $25,000 per month. With an annual operating budget of about $750,000, and full fees being only about $2,000 (among the lowest for Montreal's private clubs), the club was unable to remain operation. The organization sold the building to Concordia University. It will be renovated, and then used for meetings, events, and academic conferences.[http://now.concordia.ca/university-affairs/notices/20100913/concordia-purchases-montefiore-club.php Concordia purchases Montefiore Club - NOW - Concordia University] The proceeds from the sale of the premises will be used to pay costs and staff severances. Remaining funds, expected to amount to approximately $1.5 million, will be donated to the [[Jewish Community Foundation of Montreal]] for Jewish education, and to Concordia University to fund a Jewish studies endowment. The contents of the building, which includes artwork, will be auctioned to members, with remaining items made available to the general public. The club plans to donate its substantial archives to the [[Jewish Public Library of Montreal|Jewish Public Library]]. ==Members== Notable former members include: *[[Leo Kolber]] *[[Harry Blank]]{{cite book |title=Dictionnaire des parlementaires du Quebec, 1792-1992 |last= |first= |authorlink= |year=1993 |publisher=Presses de l'Universite Laval |location= Sainte-Foy|isbn= |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} *[[Samuel Bronfman]]{{cite book |title=The defining decade : identity, politics, and the Canadian Jewish community in the 1960s |last=Troper |first=Harold |authorlink= Harold Martin Troper |year= 2010|publisher=University of Toronto Press |location= Toronto ; Buffalo, NY|isbn= |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} *[[Charles Bronfman]]{{cite book|last=Davidson|first=Evelyn|title=Who's Who in Canadian Business, 2001|year=2001|pages=101|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o9_yWE2_BgUC&pg=PA101&lpg=PA101&dq=charles+bronfman+montefiore&source=bl&ots=cWeKXAGHjr&sig=5dlHxdSHKGec3cXQwk5_KIKF1g0&hl=en&ei=rqNKTfWCA8_1gAfKuNUY&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=charles%20bronfman%20montefiore&f=false}} *[[Sam Steinberg]] ==Presidents== Some past presidents include: *John Michaels: 1880–1882; 1892–1894 *Maxwell Goldstein: 1882–1885; 1886–1891; 1905–1906 *[[Lyon Cohen]]: 1891–1892 *Bernard Goldstein: 1894–1896 *J. Goldstein: 1896–1898 *Michael Hirsch: 1885–1886; 1896–1902; 1908–1910; 1911–1934 *Abraham Michaels: 1902–1905 *Emanuel Blout: 1906–1908 *Jacob Levi: 1910–1911 *David Kirsch: 1934–1936 *A. L. Mailman: 1936–1938 *Jack L. Klein: 1938–1943 *Joel B. Saxe: 1943–1945 *William Gittes: 1945–1947 *Samuel Moskovitch: 1947–1949 *Harry Benjamin: 1949–1951 *Arthur N. Friedman: 1951–1953 *Norman Genser: 1953–1955 *Bernard J. Lande: 1955–1957 *Arthur Pascal: 1957–1959 *Harry Wolfe: 1959–1961 *Saul E. Moskovitch: 1961–1963 *J. B. Becker: 1963–1965 *Phillip Meyerovitch: 1966–1968 *Dr. André Aisenstadt: 1968–1970 *Henry S. Weiser: 1970–1973 *Sidney Schwartz: 1973–1975 *James D. Raymond: 1975–1977 *Manuel Shacter: 1977–1979 *Nicki H. Lang: 1979–1981 ==Legacy== To support scholarships for [[Concordia University (Quebec)|Concordia University]] [[graduate student]]s, an endowment has been established. Recipients will be "Moses Montefiore Fellows". A plaque commemorating Moses Montefiore will be attached to the Guy Street building with the enscription:
"In memory of Sir Moses Montefiore for his lifelong philanthropy and service to world Jewry".[http://www.cjnews.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=19984&Itemid=86 The Canadian Jewish News - Jewish Canadian airmen buried in Britain]
==See also== *[[History of the Jews in Canada]] ==References== {{reflist|33em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|position=left|Montefoire Club}} [[Category:1880 establishments in Quebec]] [[Category:Jewish Canadian history]] [[Category:Jewish organizations based in Canada]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in Canada]] [[Category:Gentlemen's clubs in Canada]] [[Category:Concordia University]] [[Category:Organizations based in Montreal]] [[Category:Defunct organizations based in Canada]] [[Category:2010 disestablishments in Quebec]] [[Category:Jews and Judaism in Montreal]]

revision.comment: /* top */replaced poptime to population per [[Category:Articles using Template:Infobox ethnic group with deprecated parameters]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Ethnic group| |group=Mungo |image= |population='''Total:''' Fewer than 87,700 (1982)<ref>This is the estimated number of first-language speakers of the Duala language according to Ethnologue. This includes both the Duala and Mungo ethnic groups, so this number is inflated for 1982.</ref> |popplace=[[Cameroon]] |langs=[[Duala language|Duala]], [[French language|French]] |rels=Predominantly [[Christian]], [[African Traditional Religion]] |related=[[Bakole people|Bakole]], [[Bakweri]], [[Bamboko]], [[Duala people|Duala]], [[Isubu]], [[Limba people (Cameroon)|Limba]], [[Wovea]] }}
The '''Mungo''' ('''Moungo''') are an [[ethnic group]] of the [[Republic of Cameroon]]. Along with the other coastal peoples, they belong to the [[Sawa (ethnic group)|Sawa]] ethnic groups. The Mungo have historically been dominated by the [[Duala people]], and the two groups share similar cultures, histories, and claims of origin.
==History and geography== The Mungo share no singular origin story. Some claim the same history as the Duala and [[Limba people (Cameroon)|Limba]], descending from a man named [[Mbedi a Mbongo|Mbedi]]. From a place called Piti (northeast of [[Douala]]), Mbedi's sons [[Ewale a Mbedi|Ewale]] and [[Dibongo a Mbedi|Dibongo]] migrated south toward the Cameroon coast. while others trace their ancestry to a man named Lokula who migrated east from near [[Ibibio people|Efik]] territory in modern-day [[Nigeria]]. The former tradition seems more likely, however, and the Nigerian story possibly indicates that later settlers entered Limba country from Efik territories at some point and assimilated.<ref>Fanso 51.</ref>
By the 16th century, the Duala had become the leading traders in Cameroon. The Mungo provided goods and [[slave]]s to the Duala in exchange for goods obtained from the Europeans, such as alcohol, gunpowder, guns, mirrors, shoes, textiles, and tools.
In 1918, Germany lost [[World War I]], and her colonies became mandates of the [[League of Nations]]. Great Britain and France split the administration of the Kameruns, partitioning the Cameroonian Littoral. The Mungo were divided in two.
[[Image:Duala ethnic groups.png|thumb|left|325px|Map showing the location of the various Duala ethnic groups of Cameroon]] The Mungo live along the [[Mungo River (Cameroon)|Mungo River]]'s lower stretch and the creeks that feed it. Their territory straddles the border of the [[Moungo division]] of the [[Littoral Province (Cameroon)|Littoral Province]] and the [[Fako division]] of the [[Southwest Province (Cameroon)|Southwest Province]]. Fishing is the primary means of subsistence.
===Language=== The Mungo who speak a dialect of [[Duala language|Duala]].<ref>"Duala", ''Ethnologue''.</ref> Duala is part of the [[Bantu languages|Bantu]] group of the [[Niger–Congo language family]].
In addition, individuals who have attended school or lived in an urban centre usually speak a European language. For Littoral Mungo, this is [[French language|French]]; for Southwest Mungo, it is [[Cameroonian Pidgin English]] or standard [[English language|English]]; and for the Mungo it is one or the other. A growing number of the [[Anglophone Cameroonian|Anglophones]] today grow up with Pidgin as their first tongue.<ref>"Pidgin, Cameroon", ''Ethnologue''.</ref>
===Arts=== The Mungo are part of the lively musical heritage of the Cameroon Littoral. [[Ambasse bey]], a style of folk music marrying guitar with found-object percussion, developed in the 1950s in the Mungo area. [[Makossa]], a popular musical style in West and Central Africa, originated with the Duala around this same time. The style mixes [[jazz]], [[highlife]], and [[soul music|soul]] with [[music of Africa|African traditional music]].{{Citation needed|date=February 2007}}
The Mungo are regular attendees of the annual [[Ngondo]], a traditional festival of the Sawa peoples. The goal is to communicate with the ancestors and ask them for guidance and protection for the future. The festivities also include armed combat, [[beauty pageant]]s, [[pirogue]] races, and traditional [[sport wrestling|wrestling]].<ref>''Guide touristique'' 126.</ref>
==Classification== The Mungo are [[Bantu peoples|Bantu]] in language and origin. More narrowly, they fall into the Sawa, or the coastal peoples of Cameroon.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Chrispin, Dr. Pettang, directeur. ''Cameroun: Guide touristique.'' Paris: Les Éditions Wala. * Fanso, V. G. (1989). ''Cameroon History for Secondary Schools and Colleges, Vol. 1: From Prehistoric Times to the Nineteenth Century.'' Hong Kong: Macmillan Education Ltd. * Gordon, Raymond G., Jr. (ed.) (2005): "[http://www.ethnologue.org/show_language.asp?code=dua Duala]". ''Ethnologue: Languages of the World'', 15th ed. Dallas: SIL International. Accessed 6 June 2006. * Gordon, Raymond G., Jr. (ed.) (2005): "[http://www.ethnologue.org/show_language.asp?code=wes Pidgin, Cameroon]". ''Ethnologue: Languages of the World'', 15th ed. Dallas: SIL International. Accessed 6 June 2006.
==External links== * [http://www.peuplesawa.com/fr/index.php Peuple Sawa] (in French)
{{Ethnic groups in Cameroon}} [[Category:Bantu peoples]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Cameroon]] [[Category:Indigenous peoples of West Africa]]

{{Expand Indonesian|date=November 2014|Suku Dayak Ngaju}} {{Infobox ethnic group |group = '''Ngaju people'''
'''Dayak Ngaju / Dayak Baiju''' |image = [[File:Dayak Ngaju Warrior by W.T. Gordon 1857.jpg|300px]] |caption = An illustration of a Dayak Ngaju warrior. |population = 400,000 |popplace = {{flag|Indonesia}}: |region1 = [[Central Kalimantan]] |pop1 = 324,504 (2000) |ref1 = Badan Pusat Statistik - Sensus Penduduk Tahun 2000 |langs = [[Ngaju language]], [[Bakumpai language]], [[Indonesian language]] |rels = [[Christianity]] ([[Protestant Christian]] & [[Catholicism]]), [[Islam]], [[Kaharingan]] |related = [[Dayak people]] ([[Bakumpai people]], [[Meratus Dayak]]) }} '''Ngaju''' are indigenous people of [[Borneo]] from the [[Dayak people|Dayak]] group.{{cite book|author=Leo Suryadinata, Evi Nurvidya Arifin & Aris Ananta|title=Indonesia's Population: Ethnicity and Religion in a Changing Political Landscape|year=2003|publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies|isbn=981-230-212-3}} The Ngaju people first appeared as a newly recognized people group in census 2000 and were made up of 18.02% of [[Central Kalimantan]] population, which before this the Ngaju people were considered as part of the [[Dayak people]] in a 1930 census.{{cite book|author=Riwanto Tirtosudarmo|title=Mencari Indonesia: Demografi-Politik Pasca-Soeharto|year=2007|publisher=Yayasan Obor Indonesia|isbn=979-799-083-4}} They speak [[Ngaju language]]. ==Dayak Ngaju family clusters== [[File:Schwaner Ngadjoes van zuidelijk Borneo.jpg|thumb|right|Ngaju people of southern Borneo as depicted by the first explorer to Borneo, [[Carl Schwaner]], 1854.]] Based on river stream regions, the Ngaju people are divided into:- * Greater Batang Baiju - Greater Baiju River * Lesser Batang Baiju - Lesser Baiju River Based on linguistic cluster, the Ngaju people are divided into:- * Dayak Ngaju (Ngaju Kapuas) people * Dayak Kahayan (Ngaju Kahayan) people * Dayak Katingan (Ngaju Katingan) people * Dayak Mendawai people ([[Central Kalimantan]]) * Dayak [[Bakumpai people]] ([[South Kalimantan]]) * Dayak [[Meratus Dayak|Meratus people]] ([[South Kalimantan]]) * Dayak Mengkatip people ([[Central Kalimantan]]) * Dayak Berangas people ([[South Kalimantan]], which is said to be no longer identifiable and their language is no longer in existence as of 2010 due to assimilation into the mainstream Kuala [[Banjar people]]) * Dayak Beraki (Bara-ki) people (no longer in existence){{cite book|author=M. J. Melalatoa|title=Ensiklopedi Suku Bangsa Di Indonesia, Volume 1|year=1995|publisher=Departemen Pendidikan dan Kebudayaan RI|oclc=37396203}} ==Culture== ===Traditional folk songs=== * Sinta Takalupe Lunuk{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ICCEzsqvnrI&feature=related |title=lagu dayak Erika sinta takalupe lunuk |publisher=Rocky wans |accessdate=2015-08-05}} * Karungut, Kal-Teng Membangun{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O_uL2fZSdNw&feature=related |title=Karungut Kal-Teng Membangun (karungut modern) |publisher=tingang |accessdate=2015-08-05}} * Yang Mahakasih (religious song){{cite book|author=|title=Pak Siswa 2 Ktsp-revisi (tuhan Mengasihi Semua Orang)|year=2007|publisher=BPK Gunung Mulia|isbn=979-687-591-8}} ===Food=== * Bagamat, a [[giant bat]] meat gravy cooked with garlic and various vegetables.{{cite web|url=http://citizen6.liputan6.com/read/619694/nikmatnya-daging-paing-kelelawar-raksasa-khas-kalteng |title=Nikmatnya Daging Paing, Kelelawar Raksasa Khas Kalteng |author=Iwan Prasetya |publisher=Liputan6 |date=22 June 2013 |accessdate=2016-11-05}} * Karuang or Kalumpe by the [[Ma'anyan people]], a pounded [[Cassava]] leaf salad mixed with eggplant, lemongrass, onion and garlic.{{cite web|url=https://beritagar.id/artikel/piknik/sederet-kuliner-khas-kalimantan-tengah |title=Sederet kuliner khas Kalimantan Tengah |author=Febria Silaen |publisher=Beritagar |date=20 May 2016 |accessdate=2016-11-05}} * Juhu Umbut Sawit, coconut sprout salad eaten with [[sambal]] and often served during thanksgiving or wedding ceremonies. ==Notable Dayak Ngaju people== * King Maruhum, the fourth Muslim Banjar king. * Nyai Undang, Kutah Baguh queen of Tanjung Pematang Sawang kingdom. * Raden Labih, head of the Dayak Ngaju Sei Apui people. * Nicodemus Djaija Negara, a Dayak Ngaju head district of Pulau Petak. * Damang Batu, a Dayak Ngaju Tumbang Anoi Kahayan leader and chairman of Dayak Tumbang Anoi. * Damang Anggen, a Dayak Ngaju leader and head district of Mendawai Katingan. * Soera Djaja, a Dayak Ngaju head district from Kampung Rawi and a [[Central Kalimantan]] freedom fighter. * Damang Pijar, head of the Dayak people * Batur, a [[Bakumpai people|Dayak Bakumpai]] commander, [[Barito War]] veteran. * Wangkang, a [[Bakumpai people|Dayak Bakumpai]] commander, [[Barito War]] veteran. * Hausman Baboe, founder of [[Central Kalimantan]], a prominent figure in the [[Central Kalimantan]] press and founder of the first daily ''Suara Dayak'' Indonesian newspaper. * [[Tjilik Riwut]], a [[National Hero of Indonesia]], founder of [[Central Kalimantan]], a writer, a [[Central Kalimantan]] freedom fighter and former governor of [[Central Kalimantan]]. * Mahir Mahar, founder and business leader of [[Central Kalimantan]]. * Agustin Teras Narang, a [[Central Kalimantan]] governor and president of the National Dayak Customary Council. ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.joshuaproject.net/peopctry.php?rop3=107228&rog3=ID Ngaju people] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130927132638/http://www.gendercentre.org.au/resources/polare-archive/archived-articles/soft-minded-men.htm Soft Minded Men] {{Commons category|Ngaju people}} {{Ethnic groups in Indonesia}} {{Portal|Indonesia}} [[Category:Ngaju people| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Indonesia]] [[Category:Dayak people]] {{Indonesia-stub}} {{Asia-ethno-group-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2006}} [[File:Collectie Nationaal Museum van Wereldculturen AM-670-7 Paquet Kongo Haiti Pierot Barra (Vervaardiging).jpg|thumb|A paquet congo created by [[Pierrot Barra]] ({{ill|National Museum of World Cultures|nl|Nationaal Museum van Wereldculturen}})]] '''Paquet congo''' ({{lang-ht|Paket kongo}}) are [[Haiti]]an spiritual objects made by [[Haitian Vodou|vodou]] priests and priestesses ([[houngan]]s and [[Mambo (Vodou)|mambo]]s) during ceremonies. Their name comes from the ancient [[Kongo Kingdom]] in [[Africa]], where similar objects called [[nkisi|nikisi wambi]] are found.
Kongolese [[nkisi]] use different materials from the Haitian paquet, however. A paquet is a collection of magical ingredients - herbs, earth, vegetable matter - wrapped in fabric and decorated with feathers, ribbons and sequins.
Paquet congo are said to have the power of “heating” or activating the [[loa]]. Hence the term pwen cho (hot point) sometimes used to refer to them. Paquet serve as power objects and are kept on vodou altars and used in healing ceremonies. They are also used as protective amulets in people’s homes, bringing health, wealth and happiness.
Their efficacy supposedly depends on a technique of careful wrapping - seven or nine times – symbolic of an [[umbilical cord]] connecting the charm to the universe. Indeed, their appearance roughly resembles that of a human body (some have arms), and their colors and ornamentation are sometimes, but not always, symbolic of a specific loa.
[[Category:Haitian Vodou]] [[Category:Kongo culture]]

{{Orphan|date=April 2018}}
'''Potdar''' was a hereditary office held by people belonging to the [[Deshastha Brahmin]]<ref>{{cite book|title=Terrorism in Bengal: Terrorists outside Bengal deriving inspiration from and having links with Bengal terrorists|author=Amiya K. Samanta|publisher=Government of West Bengal|year=1995|page=967|quote= Potdar, Govind Narayan, Deshastha Brahmin, residence Bombay City. Owns the Pioneer Alkaline Works at Parel.}}</ref> and the [[Daivadnya Brahmin|Daivadnya]]{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} communities (sometimes by other [[Maharashtrian Brahmin|Marathi Brahmins]]), which formed part of Maratha revenue system, as well as the local administrative body in the state of [[Maharashtra]].
''Potdar,'' derived from [[Persian language|Persian]] ''Fotdar,'' literally means "purse bearar" or [[Treasurer]]. They were in charge of testing the genuineness weight of minted coins.<ref>{{Citation|title=The Journal of the administrative sciences|publisher=Patna University. Institute of Public Administration, Patna University |year=1979|volume=v. 24–25|page=96}}</ref> Along with Kulkarni,Joshi, Gurav, Lohar, Kumbhar, Parit, Nhavi, Sutar, Chambhar, Mahar and Mang,who came from different castes, the ''Potdar'' formed a part of [[Bara Balutedar]] system.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/39986188|title=Contemporary political leadership in India|last=|first=|date=1998|publisher=APH Pub. Corp|others=Bakshi, S. R. (Shiri Ram), 1935-, Sharma, Sita Ram, 1932-, Gajrani, S.|year=|isbn=9788176480079|location=New Delhi|pages=|oclc=39986188}}</ref>
The privilege of ''Potdari'' was granted by the [[Peshwa]] to a person who could advance a fixed sum of rupees to the government. The Potdar was to examine the coins used in of day-to-day transactions.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/23609308|title=Maratha administration in the 18th century|last=1945-|first=Mahajan, T. T.,|date=1990|publisher=Commonwealth Publishers|isbn=9788171690817|location=New Delhi, India|oclc=23609308}}</ref> In exchange for their services, they were granted hereditary rights (''Vatan'') to a share in the village harvest.<ref>Fukazawa, H., 1972. Rural Servants in the 18th Century Maharashtrian Village—Demiurgic or Jajmani System?. Hitotsubashi journal of economics, 12(2), pp.14-40.</ref>
''Potdar'' is a common Maharashtrian surname used by families whose ancestors held the office.

'''Prostitution in Bhutan''' is illegal<ref name="chartsbin">{{cite web|title=The Legal Status of Prostitution by Country|url=http://chartsbin.com/view/snb|website=ChartsBin|accessdate=20 January 2018}}</ref> but in many of [[Bhutan]]'s border towns there are people openly practicing in the sex trade.<ref name="bt">{{cite news|title= Unbridled flesh trade in the border town|work= [[Bhutan Times]]|date=|url= http://www.bhutantimes.bt/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2765&Itemid=9|accessdate=2011-09-18 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120331021935/http://www.bhutantimes.bt/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2765&Itemid=9 |archive-date=31 March 2012 }}</ref><ref name="bt2">{{cite news|title= Sex, sleaze and the city|work= [[Bhutan Observer]]|date=|url= http://www.bhutanobserver.bt/sex-sleaze-and-the-city/|accessdate=2011-09-18 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20120403031121/http://www.bhutanobserver.bt/sex-sleaze-and-the-city/ |archive-date= 19 January 2011 }}</ref> [[Prostitution]] mainly occurs in bars, clubs & hotels.<ref name="bt" /><ref name="bt2" /> Some of the sex workers are employed by bar and hotel owners to attract customers.<ref name="bt" /> Prostitution also occurs in the capital, [[Thimphu]].<ref name="lucky" />
There are thought to be 400 - 500 sex workers in the country, many from poor backgrounds who enter prostitution for financial reasons.<ref name="pern">{{cite web|last1=Pem|first1=Damchoe|title=400 to 500 possible sex workers in Bhutan - The Bhutanese|url=http://thebhutanese.bt/400-to-500-possible-sex-workers-in-bhutan/|website=The Bhutanese|accessdate=20 January 2018|date=29 July 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, the [[NGO]] ''Lhak-Sam'' proposed that sex work was legalised by the government, but the proposal was turned down.<ref name="lucky">{{cite web|last1=Wangmo|first1=Lucky|title=Govt shoots down proposal to legalize sex industry – Business Bhutan|url=http://www.businessbhutan.bt/businessbhutan/govt-shoots-down-proposal-to-legalize-sex-industry/|website=Business Bhutan|accessdate=20 January 2018|date=5 July 2017}}</ref>
[[Sex trafficking]] is a problem in the country.<ref name="state17" />
==Sex tourism== Bhutan is becoming a destination for [[sex tourism]] for people from the West and [[India]].<ref name="dema">{{cite web|last1=Dema|first1=Kinga|title=Sex tourism, an emerging vulnerablity|url=http://www.kuenselonline.com/sex-tourism-an-emerging-vulnerablity/|website=Kuensel|accessdate=20 January 2018|date=12 December 2015}}</ref> Some high-end [[prostitutes]] are involved, tourists being more likely to be able to afford their fees.<ref name="dema" /> Some of the tourists are looking for sex with boys and girls.Guides Association of Bhutan The ''Guides Association of Bhutan'' report some tourists are demand female 'guides' to accompany them during their stay in the country.Guides Association of Bhutan
==Legislation== The Penal Code of Bhutan criminalises prostitution:<ref name="penal">{{cite web|title=Penal Code of Bhutan|url=http://www.wipo.int/edocs/lexdocs/laws/en/bt/bt019en.pdf|publisher=Royal Government of Bhutan|accessdate=20 January 2018|date=2004}}</ref>
CHAPTER 26 - PROSTITUTION AND RELATED OFFENCES * Prostitution :373. A defendant shall be guilty of the offence of prostitution, if the defendant offers, agrees to engage, or engages in sexual conduct with another person for money or property. * Grading of Prostitution :374. The offence of prostitution shall be a misdemeanour. * Promotion of prostitution :375. A defendant shall be guilty of the offence of promotion of prostitution, if the defendant: ::(a) Owns, leases, controls, manages, supervises a [[brothel]] or otherwise keeps a prostitution business; ::(b) Procures a person for a house of prostitution; ::(c) Encourages, induces, or otherwise purposely causes another to become or remain as a prostitute; ::(d) [[Soliciting|Solicits]] a person to patronise a prostitute; ::(e) Procures a prostitute for a patron; ::(f) Requires a prostitute to give a part or all of the money or property received as a result of the prostitution. * Grading of Promotion of prostitution :376. The offence of promotion of prostitution shall be: ::(a) A misdemeanour; ::(b) A felony of the fourth degree, if the person used for prostitution is a child of above 12 years and below 18 years; or ::(c) A felony of the third degree, if the person used for prostitution is a child of 12 years and below. * Patronising a prostitute :377. A defendant shall be guilty of the offence of patronising a prostitute, if the defendant gives money, property, or other gratification to engage in sexual act. * Grading of Patronising a prostitute :378. The offence of patronising a prostitute shall be: ::(a) A misdemeanour; ::(b) A felony of the fourth degree, if the person used for prostitution is a child of above 12 years and below 18 years; or ::(c) A felony of the third degree, if the person used for prosecution is a child of 12 years and below. * Trafficking a person for prostitution :379. A defendant shall be guilty of the offence of trafficking a person for prostitution, if the defendant transports, sells or buys a person into or outside of Bhutan with the purpose of engaging that person in prostitution. * Grading of trafficking a person for prostitution :380. The offence of trafficking a person for prostitution shall be a felony of the: ::(a) Third degree; ::(b) Second degree, if the person is a child of above 12 years and below 18 years; ::(c) First degree, if the person is a child of 12 years and below.
==Sex trafficking== Bhutan is a source and destination country for women and children vulnerable to sex trafficking. Bhutanese girls, working as domestic servants and entertainers in drayungs or [[karaoke]] bars, may be subjected to sex trafficking, coerced by debt and threats of physical abuse.<ref name="state17">{{cite web|title=Bhutan 2017 Trafficking in Persons Report|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2017/271148.htm|website=U.S. Department of State}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
The [[United States Department of State]] [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] ranks Bhutan as a '[[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 2 Watch List]]' country.<ref name="state18">{{cite web |title=Bhutan 2018 Trafficking in Persons Report |url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2018/282615.htm |website=U.S. Department of State |accessdate=29 July 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://buoyantfeet.com/2017/02/01/drayang-the-dark-secret-of-bhutan/ Drayang- The Dark Secret of Bhutan]

[[File:The conference "Multiformity- Art in Public Space". The 1st action of the 1st edition of Public Art Festival.jpg|thumb|The conference "Multiformity: Art in Public Space" at the conference hall of the Piraeus st. annexe of the Benaki Museum. The 1st action of the 1st edition of Public Art Festival. From left to right: Dimitris Ginosatis, Ioannis Vikelas, Alexis Vikelas, Leonidas-Phoebus Koskos, Yiouli Rapti, Konstantina Drakopoulou, Poka-Yio, b., Kostas Theologou and Andreas Fakis. Photo by Nia Hefe Filiogianni ]] Public Art Festival is a biennial cultural framework<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.archisearch.gr/calendar-of-events/public-art-festival-2nd-edition-survival/|title=The Independent Cultural Foundation Studio 4 Presents the Public Art Festival 2nd Edition: Survival {{!}} Archisearch|date=2017-05-11|work=Archisearch|access-date=2017-07-17|language=en-US}}</ref>, established in Athens, Greece by Andreas Fakis<ref>{{Citation|last=studio 4|title=Αndreas Fakis @ Pecha Kucha Athens vol. #6, February 2014|date=2015-11-10|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A44SuhjlNUQ|accessdate=2017-07-17}}</ref> for the independent cultural organization [[Studio 4 (independent cultural organization)|Studio 4]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.studio-four.org|title=Studio 4 {{!}} independent cultural organization|website=www.studio-four.org|access-date=2017-07-17}}</ref> in order to showcase forms of visual arts, conceptual art and film<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.widewalls.ch/public-art-festival-multiformity/|title=Public Art Festival – Multiformity|last=widewalls|work=WideWalls|access-date=2017-07-17|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lifo.gr/team/arts/50700|title=Όλα για το πρώτο Φεστιβάλ Δημόσιας Τέχνης στην Αθήνα|work=LiFO|access-date=2017-07-17}}</ref> that fall into the public sphere<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://publicartfestival.gr/en/|title=Public Art Festival: Survival|website=publicartfestival.gr|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-17}}</ref>.
Public Art Festival took place for the first time in Athens during September - October 2014, under the thematic of "Multiformity". The first edition of PAF was curated by Andreas Fakis<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.benaki.gr/index.php?option=com_events&view=event&type=&id=3899&lang=en|title=More or Less |website=www.benaki.gr|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://multiformity.publicartfestival.gr/en/|title=Public Art Festival: Multiformity|website=multiformity.publicartfestival.gr|language=en-US|access-date=2017-07-17}}</ref>, was spread out in three venues, namely: the [[Benaki Museum]], the [[Greek Film Archive|Greek Film Archive - Film Museum]] and Romantso and several outdoor locations, including [[Philopappos Monument|Filopappou Hill]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.amna.gr/article/63882/To-proto-Festibal-Dimosias-Technis-xekinaei-sto-Mouseio-Mpenaki-|title=Το πρώτο Φεστιβάλ Δημόσιας Τέχνης ξεκινάει στο Μουσείο Μπενάκη |website=www.amna.gr|access-date=2017-07-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.real.gr/DefaultArthro.aspx?page=arthro&id=355134&catID=108|title=Το πρώτο Φεστιβάλ Δημόσιας Τέχνης|access-date=2017-07-17}}</ref>, where the press conference of PAF took place and several walls, where murals were created and conserved.

revision.text:
'''Public trial''' or '''open trial''' is a [[trial (law)|trial]] open to public, as opposed to the [[secret trial]]. The term should not be confused with [[show trial]].
==United States== The [[Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution]] establishes the right of the accused to a public trial.
The right to a public trial is strictly enforced, but is not absolute. Trials may in exceptional cases be regulated. Closures are decided case-by-case by the judge evaluating a claimed danger to a substantial or legitimate public interest. But whatever the interest at stake, the likelihood of danger to that interest must meet a "‘substantial probability’ test".<ref name=PressEnterpriseII>[https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/historics/USSC_CR_0478_0001_ZO.html Press-Enterprise Co. v. Superior Court (1986)]</ref> Examples of cases presenting closure issues include [[organized crime]] cases (overall security concerns), [[rape]] cases (decency concerns), [[Minor (law)|juvenile]] cases,<ref name=overview>[http://faculty.ncwc.edu/mstevens/410/410lect24.htm Overview of the Sixth Amendment rights] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121210082619/http://faculty.ncwc.edu/mstevens/410/410lect24.htm |date=2012-12-10 }}</ref> and through the [[Silent witness rule]] and/or [[Classified Information Procedures Act]], cases involving sensitive or '[[classified information|classified]]' information.<ref>See Ellis' decision in the US V Rosen case, who calls the Silent Witness Rule a 'partial closing' of the trial</ref>
Trials may be closed at the behest of the government only if it can show "an overriding interest based on findings that closure is essential to preserve higher values and is narrowly tailored to serve that interest".<ref name=Waller>[https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/historics/USSC_CR_0467_0039_ZO.html Waller v. Georgia (1984)]</ref> The accused may also request a closure of the trial; in such a case, it must be demonstrated that "first, there is a substantial probability that the defendant's right to a fair trial will be prejudiced by publicity that closure would prevent, and second, reasonable alternatives to closure cannot adequately protect the defendant's fair trial rights".
But before a judge can close a courtroom, the judge must consider all potential alternatives to closure. This is a very strict standard; the Supreme Court has held that "trial courts are required to consider alternatives to closure even when they are not offered by the parties," or by anyone else.<ref name=Presley>[https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/09-5270.ZPC.html Presley v. Georgia (2010)]</ref> In other words, a judge who does not want to be reversed on appeal must be confident that there cannot possibly be any alternative to closure that might later be conjured up by some appellate lawyer.
==Canada== Pursuant to the [[open court principle]] and related legislation, legal proceedings are generally open to the public and the media.
Section 135(1) of the ''Courts of Justice Act'' (Ontario) states the general principle that "all court hearings shall be open to the public". In Quebec, however, under the Quebec Act 1774 the French legal system (including non-public trials) was allowed to remain intact and there is no requirement in Quebec that trials be public.
==Soviet Union== In [[Soviet Union]] the terms "open trial" (открытый процесс) and "public trial" (публичный процесс) differed. The term "open trial" implied the possibility for public to be present at the hearings. The term "public trial" implied the purposeful presentation of the process to wide public. Public trials were usually widely discussed in media and hearings were often arranged in larger [[auditoria]]. While the Soviet public trials are commonly associated with [[Stalin era]] [[show trials]], such as [[Moscow Trials]], nevertheless in [[Russian culture]] the term "public trial" did not acquire negative connotations, despite the apparent attributes of a show, primarily because the publicity of any information in pre-[[glasnost]] era was severely limited by the Soviet state. The term "show trial" corresponds to Russian "показной процесс" (''pokaznoy process'').
==See also== * [[Open court principle]] * [[Silent witness rule]] * [[Classified Information Procedures Act]] * [[United States v. Franklin]] * [[Thomas Andrews Drake]]
==References== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070811082603/http://members.mobar.org/civics/PublicTrial.htm History of the right to public trial] {{reflist|refs =
<!-- Unused citation <ref name=wydbor> [https://fas.org/sgp/jud/drake/031111-defresponse68.pdf DEFENDANT’S RESPONSE TO GOVERNMENT’S MOTION FOR AN IN CAMERA HEARING], Wyda & Borman, March 2011, (Silent Witness Rule violates right to Public Trial), from Federation of American Scientists website. </ref> --> }}
{{Sixth Amendment|public|state=expanded}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Public Trial}} [[Category:Types of trials]] [[Category:Public sphere|Trial]]
